muhurat: Sunrise to Rohini end (approx 6:30 AM–1:30 PM) moneycontrol​
significance: Fast for family prosperity, relief from poverty and misfortune, especially observed by married women.
katha: Legend tells a devotee woman was freed from endless suffering and poverty by fasting on Rohini days for Krishna; her family’s fortune reversed by the Nakshatra’s grace.
morning: Wake during Brahma Muhurta, bathe, wear clean light clothes; take sankalpa to observe Rohini fast for family welfare; set up Krishna image.
daytime: Maintain simple or nirjal fast, chant “Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya,” read Vishnu/Krishna stotras, avoid anger and harsh speech.
mainpuja: Perform Krishna puja when Rohini is strong: offer tulsi, butter, sugar; sing bhajans, do aarti to Krishna.
fasting-rules: Women usually observe from sunrise till Rohini ends, then break with light satvik food after offering naivedya to Krishna.
daan: Wheat flour sweets, curd, clothes for Brahmins or girls.
notes: 1 Jan – Rohini Vrat – “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108 times.​

significance: Bi‑monthly Shiva fast; Guru (Thursday) Pradosh grants wisdom, career growth, and removal of past karmic burdens.
katha: Devas once prayed to Shiva during Pradosh to be freed from asuras; pleased, Shiva danced Tandava and restored their power, establishing Pradosh as a powerful time.
morning: Morning bath, white/yellow clothes; light diya in Shiv corner, resolve to fast till Pradosh puja; recite “Om Namah Shivaya.”
daytime: Keep fast with fruits/milk or simple phalahar, read Shiva Purana, avoid rajasic food and negative thoughts.
mainpuja: In Pradosh Kaal, perform abhishekam of Shivalinga with water, milk, curd, honey, ghee; offer bilva leaves, incense, lamp; chant Mahamrityunjaya or “Om Namah Shivaya” 108 times and do aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast typically from sunrise to after Pradosh puja; break with satvik food after offering naivedya to Shiva. Stricter observers may continue till next morning.
daan: Milk, curd, ghee, white clothes, bilva leaves to temple or poor.
notes: Guru Pradosh Vrat – “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108 times; “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108 times.

significance: Marks conclusion of Shakambhari Navratri; worship of the vegetable-giving form of Devi for nourishment, crop protection, and rain.
katha: During a severe famine, Devi manifested as Shakambhari, feeding people with vegetables and fruits, ending their starvation; devotees honor her gratitude on this full moon.
morning: Morning snan, clean altar, install Shakambhari/Devi image; arrange vegetables, fruits, greens on a decorated thali.
daytime: Observe light fast or satvik diet; chant Durga Saptashati or Devi stotras; prepare vegetarian bhog from seasonal produce.
mainpuja: At evening, offer all vegetables/fruits to the Goddess, do Kumkum, turmeric, flowers, and aarti; distribute cooked prasad to family and poor.
fasting-rules: If fasting, maintain fruits/water through day and break after Purnima puja with bhog; many avoid onion/garlic whole day.
daan: Vegetables, grains, fruits to poor, cows, or gaushala; annadaan.
notes: ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 times.

significance: Full moon fast for punya, prosperity, and beginning of Magh snan period in North India.
katha: Scriptures describe Purnima as day when Vishnu’s grace flows strongly; Pausha Purnima marks start of sacred river baths that wash away sins.
morning: Early holy bath (preferably in river or using Ganga jal), wear clean clothes, take vow to fast and donate; set up Vishnu picture.
daytime: Observe fast on water/fruits or simple one‑meal fast; chant Vishnu Sahasranama, perform japa.
mainpuja: Perform Satyanarayan/Vishnu puja in evening; offer kheer, fruits, tulsi leaves, then do aarti.
fasting-rules: Break fast after moonrise or after completion of Satyanarayan katha with satvik bhojan.
daan: Rice, kheer, blankets, sesame, jaggery.
notes: ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 times.

significance: Mothers fast for welfare and longevity of children; removes “sankat” (troubles) from family life.
katha: Story tells of a poor woman whose child repeatedly fell ill; upon keeping Sakat Chauth fast and worshipping Ganesha with sincerity, her child recovered and lived long.
morning: Pre‑dawn bath, wear clean clothes, take sankalpa to fast for children’s protection; set up Ganesha idol with wheat lamp ( दीपक ).
daytime: Maintain nirjal or phalahar fast, prepare til‑gud and rewri; repeat “Om Gan Ganapataye Namah” japa through the day.
mainpuja: In evening, after sighting Moon or at Ganesha puja time, offer til‑gud laddoos, durva, red flowers; recite Sakat Chauth katha and perform aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast is broken only after offering water/argya to Moon and then partaking a small piece of til‑gud prasad.
daan: Til (sesame), gud (jaggery), blankets, sweets to children and poor.
notes: ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times

significance: Monthly Sankashti with special form of Ganesha worshipped for removal of obstacles and wisdom.
katha: Each Sankashti Chaturthi has a specific name and form of Ganesha; Lambodara is pot‑bellied one who digests devotees’ sorrows.
morning: Same start as Sakat: bath, sankalpa; arrange special Lambodara Ganesha image or picture.
daytime: Fast in similar Sankashti way; read Lambodara Sankashti Vrata Katha if available or generic Sankashti katha.
mainpuja: Perform Ganesha puja at night before/after Moonrise; offer 21 durva, modak, chant Ganesh Atharvashirsha.
fasting-rules: Break fast only after seeing Moon and offering arghya and naivedya to both Moon and Ganesha.
daan: Modak, fruits, textbooks or notebooks for students.
notes: ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times

significance: Fast to remove fear, black magic, and karmic obstacles; grants courage and protection.
katha: A devotee once tormented by evil forces was saved by chanting Bhairav mantras on Kalashtami; Shiva as Bhairav promised to protect those who keep this fast.
morning: Morning bath, black/white clothes; set up Bhairav or Shiva image, pledge to fast.
daytime: Simple or nirjal fast; chant “Om Hraum Batuk Bhairavaya Namah,” read Kalbhairav Katha, feed dogs.
mainpuja: At night, especially close to midnight, perform Bhairav puja with mustard oil, black sesame, coconut; offer alcohol-free prasad; do aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast kept till next morning after offering food to Bhairav or feeding dogs/crows; then take simple food.
daan: Black sesame, oil, food to dogs and poor.
notes: “ॐ कालभैरवाय नमः” 108 times.​

significance: Monthly remembrance of Krishna’s birth; for bhakti, protection, and fulfillment of desires.
katha: In addition to annual Janmashtami, some Vaishnavas remember Krishna’s birth every month on Ashtami; Krishna promised to uplift those who remember his avatar regularly.
morning: Morning snan, set Krishna cradle (jhula), decorate with flowers; take sankalpa for fast.
daytime: Light phalahar or milk/fruit fast; chant “Hare Krishna” Mahamantra, read Bhagavad Gita.
mainpuja: At midnight, perform Krishna abhishek with milk, curd, honey; swing the cradle, sing aarti and kirtan, distribute panjiri/prasad.
fasting-rules: Fast is broken after midnight puja with Krishna’s bhog, then simple food if health permits; some break next morning.
daan: Butter, sugar, fruits, sweets to children or temples.
notes: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108 times.

significance: Marks first day of Pongal in South India; symbolic discarding of old and inviting new prosperity.
katha: People burn old items in Bhogi bonfire, signifying burning of negative habits; gods are thanked for harvest.
morning: Pre‑dawn bath, home cleaning; place old unwanted items for symbolic discard; decorate threshold with rangoli.
daytime: Join community Bhogi fire, pray for removal of past negativity, cook traditional dishes.
mainpuja: Evening family gathering, music, sharing of sweets; simple aarti at home shrine.
fasting-rules: No strict fast; focus on cleanliness and gratitude.
daan: Blankets, old but usable clothes to poor.

significance: Punjabi harvest festival thanking fire and Sun; associated with new brides and newborns.
katha: Popular lore connects Lohri with Dulha Bhatti, a local “Robin Hood” who saved girls from oppression; songs praise his bravery.
morning: Evening bath, wear traditional attire; gather around bonfire.
daytime: Circle the fire, offer sesame, jaggery, peanuts; sing Lohri songs, especially for newborn boys/girls.
mainpuja: Maintain bonfire, perform simple aarti facing fire; distribute rewari, gajak.
fasting-rules: No fast; emphasis on festive food and sharing.
daan: Til, gud, peanuts, popcorn to community and poor.

muhurat: Sankranti moment 3:13 PM; Punya Kaal ~3:13–4:58 PM (Delhi) goodreturns​
significance: Marks Sun’s transition to Capricorn; start of Uttarayana, very auspicious for snan, daan, and new ventures.
katha: Legend says Surya visits his son Shani in his realm on this day, reducing conflicts; Bhishma chose to leave his body in Uttarayana for moksha.
morning: Early snan in river or at home with Ganga jal; offer water to rising Sun with “Om Ghrini Suryaya Namah.”
daytime: During Punya Kaal, perform til‑snan, til‑daan, chant Aditya Hridayam, visit temple.
mainpuja: Evening socialize, fly kites (in many regions), share til‑gud laddoos saying “til‑gul ghya, god god bola.”
fasting-rules: No strict fast required; some keep partial fast and take khichdi or til‑gud; focus is on holy bath and charity.
daan: Sesame, jaggery, blankets, khichdi, utensils. goodreturns​
notes: “ॐ घृणि सू्र्याय नमः” 108 times.

significance: Tamil harvest festival, thanking Sun and Mother Earth for abundance.
katha: Story of Surya being honored as life‑giver of crops; farmers offer first rice of harvest back to divine.
morning: Clean courtyard, draw kolam; set earthen pot in east‑facing direction for cooking Pongal.
daytime: Boil newly harvested rice with milk and jaggery; as it overflows, shout “Pongalo Pongal” in joy, symbolizing abundance.
mainpuja: Offer Pongal to Surya Dev with sugarcane, turmeric plants; perform aarti of Sun and cows.
fasting-rules: No compulsory fasting; feast on Pongal dishes after offering.
daan: Rice, jaggery, sugarcane, utensils, cattle feed.

significance: Cleanses sins via six types of sesame use; bestows health, prosperity, and detachment.
katha: A pious but miserly woman did intense worship yet never practiced charity; Vishnu appeared and taught her to use sesame in six forms of daan and worship, granting her real merit.
morning: Brahma Muhurta bath with sesame in water; take sankalpa for Shattila fast, worship Vishnu.
daytime: Use sesame in bath, til‑daan, til‑deep, til‑havan, til‑naivedya; chant Vishnu Sahasranama; avoid grains.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja or Satyanarayan katha; offer til sweets, tulsi, then aarti.
fasting-rules: Strict fast from sunrise to next day after Parana (breaking) in Dwadashi tithi; phalahar or only water depending on strength.
daan: Sesame, food, blankets, cows’ fodder.
notes: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108/1008 times

significance: Meru (cosmic mountain) worship for stability and dharma; linked with performing shraddha or homa.
katha: Puranas mention Meru as axis of universe; worship grants spiritual elevation and stability.
morning: Morning bath, sankalpa; set up kalash representing Meru; invite deities.
daytime: Perform simple puja or homa, reciting Vishnu mantras; meditate on stability in life.
mainpuja: Offer naivedya, do aarti; some perform small shraddha for ancestors.
fasting-rules: No fixed fast; optional upvas/fruit fast according to capability.
daan: Grains, ghee, dakshina to Brahmins.

significance: Friday Pradosh brings harmony, luxuries, and marital happiness; removes debts and sorrow.
katha: Devas once worshipped Shiva on Pradosh falling on Friday to regain lost prosperity; Shiva granted wealth and harmony.
morning: Morning snan, vow to fast; arrange Shivalinga with white flowers.
daytime: Maintain phalahar fast, repeat “Om Namah Shivaya,” read Shiva tandava stotra.
mainpuja: Perform full Pradosh puja as earlier described: abhishek with Panchamrit, bilva, incense, lamp, mantra japa, aarti.
fasting-rules: Break fast after Pradosh puja and naivedya with light, non‑spicy food.
daan: Milk, white sweets, rice, money to poor couples.
notes: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108; “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108.

significance: Monthly Shiva night for inner purification, overcoming tamas, and seeking moksha.
katha: Linked with Shiva drinking halahal poison and protecting the worlds; devotees emulate his sacrifice through fasting and night vigil.
morning: Morning bath, simple clothes; take sankalpa to observe fast, worship Shivling.
daytime: Follow upvas with water/milk or fruits; chant “Om Namah Shivaya” throughout the day; avoid onion/garlic.
mainpuja: At night, ideally in four prahar, do abhishekam with water, milk, honey; offer bilva, dhatura; recite Shiv Chalisa, Mahamrityunjaya, perform aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast may be nirjal till next morning; Parana after offering water to rising Sun and Shiva puja at dawn.
daan: Milk, bel leaves, ghee, food, blankets.
notes: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” many malas; Mahamrityunjaya 108.

daytime: Maintain silence, meditate, read scriptures; perform pitru tarpan if traditions allow.
mainpuja: Simple diya and aarti in evening without loud speech; mentally chant mantras.
fasting-rules: Some observe fast or take only one simple meal after sunset; maintain silence as much as possible.
daan: Food, blankets, sesame, ghee to poor and Brahmins.
notes: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108; “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108.

significance: South Indian pitru day; special tarpan and shraddha for deceased family members.
katha: Belief that Pitru visit earth; proper tarpan here grants peace to their souls and blessings to descendants.
morning: Morning bath, wear traditional dhoti/sari; arrange pitru thali with water, black sesame, darbha grass.
daytime: Perform tarpan with mantras guided by family priest, remembering lineage.
mainpuja: Light lamp for ancestors, simple home puja.
fasting-rules: Usually no feast till rites done; then satvik meal shared with family.
daan: Food, rice, clothes, dakshina to Brahmins.

significance: Nine‑day Navratri in Magh (lesser‑known) for sadhana, health, and success.
katha: Devi is believed to be especially accessible in four Navratris; Magha Navratri is for inner sadhana and mantra japa.
morning: Ghatasthapana in morning, install Kalash and Durga image; take sankalpa for 9‑day vrat.
daytime: Daily partial fast, chant Durga Saptashati or select chapters; avoid tamasic food.
mainpuja: Evening aarti and bhajans, kumkum tilak to Devi and women.
fasting-rules: Many take one‑time satvik meal during the nine days; break formally on Navami with kanya pujan.
daan: Food, fruits, clothes to girls (Kanya pujan); sweets.
notes: “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108 daily through Navratri.

significance: First sighting of new moon after Amavasya; believed to bring peace of mind and emotional stability.
katha: Puranas say Chandra was cursed by Daksha and later restored by Shiva; worshipping Chandra helps balance mind and relationships.

daytime: Prepare small plate with rice, milk sweets, water.
mainpuja: After sighting crescent Moon, offer arghya (water) and rice, chant “Om Chandraya Namah,” pray for calm mind.
fasting-rules: No formal fast; some eat after Chandra darshan as symbolic restart.
daan: Rice, white sweets, milk to children/poor.
notes: “ॐ चन्द्राय नमः” 11–27 times.

significance: Birth anniversary of Ganesha (mainly in Maharashtra); for wisdom, success, and removal of obstacles.
katha: Texts describe Ganesha appearing to protect devotees at start of a new creation cycle; this tithi honors his role as Vighnaharta.

daytime: Prepare modak, laddoos; chant Ganesh Atharvashirsha, decorate altar with durva and flowers.
mainpuja: Perform main puja before midday: offer 21 durva, modak, do aarti, kirtan; children participate.
fasting-rules: Some keep fast till noon puja then eat prasad; others do full‑day phalahar fast.
daan: Modak, fruits, notebooks/pens for students.
notes: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times.

significance: Marks start of Vasant (spring); Saraswati worship for knowledge, arts, music, exams.
katha: Brahma is said to have created universe and then invoked Saraswati to bring order; she bestows speech, learning, and creativity.

daytime: Keep books and tools near altar, avoid touching them without puja; children do vidyarambh (first writing) this day.
mainpuja: Perform Saraswati puja with yellow flowers, sweets, lamp; chant “Ya Kundendu Tusharahara dhavala,” offer prasad to students.
fasting-rules: No strict fast; light satvik food; some students voluntarily reduce distractions that day instead.
daan: Stationery, books, clothing to students; food at schools.
notes: “ॐ ऐं सरस्वत्यै नमः” 108/1008 times.​

daytime: Chant “Om Namah Shivaya,” recite Shiva Panchakshari, offer milk and bilva; some observe fast till darshan.
mainpuja: Temple abhishekam of Nataraja, deepa aradhana, special alankar; home aarti with camphor.
fasting-rules: Optional upvas to be broken after main temple/home puja with simple satvik food.
daan: Oil, lamps, white clothes, food at Shiva temples.

daytime: Perform brief homa with family priest or as per tradition, chanting Gayatri and simple mantras.
mainpuja: Offer final aarti to Agni; mentally dedicate all actions to Ishvara.
fasting-rules: No formal fast; simple satvik meals recommended, avoiding onion/garlic on homa days.
daan: Ghee, grains, wood for fire, dakshina to purohit.
notes: Mostly followed in orthodox Vedic households; you may omit if not doing agnihotra.

significance: Start of the holy Magha month in North India, considered highly auspicious for snan, daan and japa.moneycontrol​

daytime: Continue normal work while including daily small acts of charity and extra chanting.
mainpuja: Simple diya at home altar, short aarti.
fasting-rules: No mandatory fast; some follow Monday/Thursday fasts through Magha.
daan: Food, blankets, sesame, ghee to poor.
notes: Sets background for Mauni Amavasya and Magh Mela.

significance: Small Vedic offering/oblation day noted in some panchangs for prosperity and wish‑fulfilment.moneycontrol​
katha: Mini‑yajna to harmonise elements and remove subtle obstacles; often clubbed with simple homa.

daytime: Offer oblations of ghee and sesame or havan‑samagri into fire with simple mantras.
mainpuja: Aarti to fire and deities invoked.
fasting-rules: No fast; homa done before meals.
daan: Havan samagri, ghee, fruits for distributing.
notes: Listed mainly as a panchangic/ritual note; optional for lay‑householders.

mainpuja: Simple aarti or lamp waving before his photo; satsang or talks in institutions.
fasting-rules: No fast prescribed; some youth voluntarily avoid harmful habits that day.

significance: Marks Sun beginning its northward movement; considered especially auspicious for new ventures, marriages, and spiritual practices.moneycontrol​

morning: Morning snan and Arghya to Sun; same as Sankranti but with focus on new cycle.
daytime: Plan to start any new sadhana or study on this day; keep attitude of positivity.
mainpuja: Simple evening deepa and aarti to Sun or at home altar.
fasting-rules: No fast; often combined with Makar Sankranti observances.
daan: Food, ghee, blankets.

daytime: Chant “Swamiye Saranam Ayyappa,” recite Ayyappa bhajans, keep sattvic food.
mainpuja: Watch/mentally attend Makaravilakku aarti time; light lamp at home and pray for protection.

daytime: Chant Vishnu Sahasranama, especially Kurma‑related chapters, avoid rajasic food.
mainpuja: Simple Vishnu puja in evening; offer kheer, tulsi, do aarti.
fasting-rules: Follow Ekadashi‑type diet extended into Dwadashi; Parana after offering naivedya.
daan: Grains, sweets, cows’ fodder, dakshina.
notes: Often quietly followed in Vaishnava households; you may treat as sub‑row under Shattila if space is tight.

daytime: Feed cows special food, do pradakshina, touch feet for blessings.
mainpuja: Simple aarti of cows, then of home altar; family feast.
fasting-rules: No fast; focus on joy and gratitude.
daan: Cattle feed, jaggery, bananas for cows.
notes: Predominantly Tamil & rural areas.

daytime: Day spent visiting relatives, sharing food.
mainpuja: Bonfire burning of meji in early morning; simple prayers.
fasting-rules: No fast; rather a feast festival.
daan: Food, especially rice‑based sweets, to neighbours and poor.
notes: Regional but nice to list in “Festivals” sheet.

notes: As above—record as ritual entry.

significance: Commemoration of consecration (pratishtha) of Ram Lalla idol in new Ayodhya temple.moneycontrol​
katha: Narratives of Rama’s birth and temple restoration inspire dharma, unity, and devotion; this day marks his formal prana‑pratishtha.
morning: Morning snan; place Ram Lalla image; decorate with flowers.
daytime: Recite Ramayana, chant “Shri Ram Jai Ram Jai Jai Ram,” keep sattvic diet.
mainpuja: Perform simple aarti at noon, offer halwa, fruits; watch/live‑stream Ayodhya events if possible.
fasting-rules: No fixed fast; some keep partial upvas out of devotion.
daan: Food, sweets to children, donations to temples.
notes: Newer entry in panchangs; important for Pan‑India devotees.

significance: Combined worship to enhance harmony, remove obstacles, and grant family happiness.moneycontrol​
katha: Legend says Parvati fashioned Ganesha as her guardian; both mother and son protect households when worshipped together.
morning: Morning bath; place images of Gauri and Ganesha together; vow for family welfare.
daytime: Prepare simple naivedya like modak, kheer, fruits; chant Parvati and Ganesha mantras.
mainpuja: Perform joint puja, kumkum to Gauri, durva and modak to Ganesha; do aarti.
fasting-rules: Optional partial fast until puja is completed; then partake prasad.
daan: Modak, bangles, kumkum, fruits.
notes: Good to highlight for “family”‑themed vrats.

significance: Monthly or special Shashthi for victory over enemies, courage, and spiritual conquest.moneycontrol​
katha: Remembers Murugan’s victory over demon Surapadma; he grants sharp intellect and valor.
morning: Morning bath, install Murugan/Kartikeya image or spear (vel).
daytime: Fast lightly, chant “Om Saravanabhavaya Namah,” read Kanda Puran stories.
mainpuja: Offer red flowers, fruits, especially in evening; do aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast may be till evening puja then break with prasad.
daan: Fruits, sweets, clothes for boys/students.
notes: “ॐ सरवनभवाय नमः” 108 times.

significance: Saptami dedicated to Sun; removes eye diseases, ill‑health, and gives fame.moneycontrol​
katha: A king with incurable illness was cured by observing Bhanu Saptami with Surya snan and daan; Vishnu praised this vrat in Puranas.
morning: Dawn bath preferably in river or with Ganga jal; offer arghya to rising Sun chanting Surya mantras.
daytime: Keep partial fast or light sattvic food, chant Aditya Hridayam or Surya Ashtakam.
mainpuja: Simple evening deepa to Sun at home altar (facing east), then aarti.
fasting-rules: Some keep fast till midday then break with wheat‑based satvik food.
daan: Wheat, jaggery, red clothes, eye‑medicine donation.
notes: “ॐ सूर्याय नमः” or “ॐ घृणि सू्र्याय नमः” 108.

significance: Celebrates Sun’s chariot turning more decisively northwards; considered Surya Jayanti in some texts.panditjionway​
katha: Story: King Yashovarma’s sick son was cured after sage advised Ratha Saptami snan and daan; observing this removes past karmic debts.
morning: Prepare leaves/flowers, draw Sun’s chariot symbol on floor; morning snan with seven arka leaves on body.
daytime: Offer arghya to Sun seven times, circumambulate a symbolic chariot drawing; chant Surya mantras.
mainpuja: Evening diya and Surya aarti.
fasting-rules: Many do fast till noon or sunset depending on tradition; then break with satvik food.
daan: Arka leaves, wheat, jaggery, copper vessels.
notes: In South, very elaborately observed; some merge with Bhanu Saptami observance.

significance: Celebrates Narmada river’s appearance; believed to grant punya equivalent to Ganga snan.moneycontrol​
katha: Puranas describe Narmada as born from Shiva’s sweat; her waters destroy sins quicker than fire burns cotton.
morning: Bath or symbolic snan with Narmada/Ganga jal; set small Narmada photo or Shiva linga.
daytime: Chant “Narmade Har” or Shiva mantras, keep sattvic food.
mainpuja: Offer deep daan (floating lamps) in river or water bowl at home; aarti.
fasting-rules: No strict fast; some keep till evening river worship.
daan: Lamps, food, clothes to riverbank priests/poor.
notes: Important in MP, Gujarat; list as festival.

significance: Panchangic milestone marking start of a cosmic manvantara of Brahma Savarni in traditional calculations.moneycontrol​
katha: Puranas talk of 14 Manus; Brahma Savarni is a future Manu; date is symbolic rather than practical.
morning: Normal daily snan and puja.
daytime: If keen, read a small Purana excerpt about Manus and cosmic cycles.
mainpuja: Simple deepa and aarti.
fasting-rules: No fast; purely scriptural note.
daan: None specific; general charity as wished.
notes: You may keep this in a separate “Panchangic/Other” sheet if focusing on devotional use.

significance: Commemorates the day Bhishma Pitamah chose to leave his body on arrow bed, giving teachings to Yudhishthira.moneycontrol​
katha: Mahabharata recounts Bhishma instructing on Rajdharma and Vishnu Sahasranama; observing this vrat grants steadfastness and devotion.
morning: Morning bath, remember Bhishma; keep Vishnu photo with his image if available.
daytime: Chant Vishnu Sahasranama, read Mahabharata portions (Shanti Parva); cultivate vows like truth and brahmacharya in spirit.
mainpuja: Simple aarti in evening to Vishnu; silently offer gratitude to ancestors.
fasting-rules: Some keep partial fast; break with satvik food after sunset.
daan: Food, blankets, donations in memory of elders.
notes: Good day for reciting Vishnu Sahasranama at least once.

significance: Monthly Ashtami vrat to seek protection, strength, and removal of inner enemies.moneycontrol​
katha: Devi promised in scriptures to protect those who remember her on Ashtami with pure heart; many treat it like a mini Navratri day.
morning: After snan, install Durga picture; wear clean red/yellow clothes; sankalpa for fast.
daytime: Spend day chanting “Ya Devi Sarvabhuteshu” stotras, reading Durga Saptashati portions; avoid negative speech.
mainpuja: Evening Durga puja with kumkum, flowers, incense; aarti and offering of kheer or fruits.
fasting-rules: Fast is often upvas on fruits/milk, broken after sunset and puja; some take one meal only.
daan: Food, fruits, clothes to girls and women (Kanya).

significance: Tamil lamp festival day each month, glorifying deepa for Shiva/Murugan; removes darkness and sins.moneycontrol​
katha: Linked to story of Shiva appearing as infinite column of light (Ardhanarishvara) and Murugan as divine child; lamps represent that jyoti.
morning: Evening bath; clean puja area.
daytime: Arrange many oil lamps on doorstep and altar; chant Shiva/Kartikeya mantras.
mainpuja: Light rows of deepa at dusk; perform aarti, offer naivedya.
fasting-rules: No set fast; some keep light diet till deepa lighting.
daan: Oil, wicks, lamps to temple; food to poor.
notes: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” or “ॐ सरवनभवाय नमः” 108.

significance: Same as first Rohini row: for prosperity, freedom from suffering; mainly Jain and Vaishnava observance.moneycontrol​
katha: As previously summarised: woman freed from poverty through Rohini fasts by Krishna’s grace.
morning: Same pattern as 1 Jan Rohini Vrat.
daytime: Same.
mainpuja: Same.
fasting-rules: Same.
daan: Wheat sweets, curd, clothes.
notes: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108.

significance: Day for observing fast and remembering Bhishma’s advice; considered auspicious for Vaishnavas.moneycontrol​
katha: It’s said Bhishma recommended reciting Vishnu Sahasranama; those who do so on this day receive special grace.
morning: Morning snan, remember Bhishma and Vishnu; sankalpa for simple fast.
daytime: Chant Vishnu Sahasranama, meditate on dharma and duty.
mainpuja: Offer tulsi, flowers, kheer to Vishnu; aarti.
fasting-rules: Upvas till evening or next morning depending on health; break with satvik food.
daan: Food, blankets, dakshina to Brahmins.
notes: Can be grouped thematically with Bhishma Ashtami for teaching content.

significance: Highly auspicious Ekadashi said to free from even heinous sins, giving victory (jaya) in both worlds.moneycontrol​
katha: Katha tells of Malin Devi and Malyavan Gandharva who sinned and became ghosts; by fasting on Jaya Ekadashi they were freed and regained celestial forms.
morning: Early snan, resolve to observe strict Ekadashi: no grains, only water or fruits as per capacity; worship Vishnu.
daytime: Spend day in japa, listening to Jaya Ekadashi katha, avoid gossip and anger.
mainpuja: Perform evening Vishnu puja or Satyanarayan katha; offer fruits, tulsi, then aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast from sunrise to next‑day Dwadashi Parana, after sunrise and puja; avoid salt if doing nirjala or strict version.
daan: Food, blankets, sesame, donations at Vishnu temples.

significance: Marks the death anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi; reflection on ahimsa, truth, and national service.moneycontrol​
katha: No religious katha; focus on his life of satyagraha and sacrifice for India’s freedom.
morning: Simple bath and silent prayer for peace; two‑minute silence at 11 AM (common).
daytime: Read a passage from his writings, discuss ahimsa with children.
mainpuja: Attend/organise bhajan sessions (e.g., “Raghupati Raghav”), peace gatherings.
fasting-rules: No fast required; some choose voluntary simplicity in food.
daan: Food, support to ashrams/charities.
notes: Include in “events” sheet as a national spiritual remembrance.

significance: Second Pradosh in month; Friday variant again focused on luxury, marriage harmony, and clearing debts.moneycontrol​
katha: Same base Pradosh story: Devas saved by Shiva’s dance during Pradosh; on Fridays Lakshmi’s grace combines with Shiva’s.
morning: Morning snan, sankalpa to fast; white/green clothes.
daytime: Phalahar fast, Shiva nama‑japa, reading Shiva Purana.
mainpuja: Full Pradosh abhishek and aarti as described in earlier Pradosh entries.
fasting-rules: Break fast after Pradosh puja with light food.
daan: Milk, rice, sweets to poor couples/priests.
notes: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108; Mahamrityunjaya 108.

significance: Day to break the previous Ekadashi fast properly, maintaining the punya of the vrat.panchang​
katha: Puranas say improper Parana spoils Ekadashi fruits; Vishnu told devotees to break fast in Dwadashi with shraddha, feeding Brahmins and poor.
morning: Morning bath; worship Vishnu briefly, remembering previous Ekadashi sankalpa.
daytime: Prepare light satvik items (kichdi, fruits, curd rice) for Parana.
mainpuja: Short evening aarti to Vishnu or Satyanarayan as thanksgiving.
fasting-rules: Break Ekadashi fast after sunrise in proper Dwadashi tithi; start with water, tulsi, then light food.
daan: Food, fruits, buttermilk, grains to poor/Brahmins.
notes: Include only if you are tracking Parana days in your sheet.panchang​

significance: Sunday Pradosh (Ravi) blesses with health, fame and relief from Surya‑related doshas like ego, authority issues.panchang​
katha: Devas approached Shiva during Pradosh to regain lost radiance; he restored their tejas. On a Sunday he also pacified Sun’s fierce energy.
morning: Morning snan; resolve Pradosh fast; arrange Shivalinga with flowers.
daytime: Phalahar fast; read Shiva Sahasranama or Shiva Purana; avoid harsh speech and anger.
mainpuja: In Pradosh Kaal, do Panchamrit abhishekam, bilva‑archana, incense, lamp; chant “Om Namah Shivaya” 108 times; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast from sunrise to after Pradosh puja; break with light satvik food after offering naivedya.
daan: Ghee, wheat, jaggery, white clothes.
notes: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108; “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108.

significance: Birth anniversary of Bhakti saint Ravidas; promotes equality, devotion, and service.astroyogi​
katha: Born in Varanasi, Ravidas preached one God, caste‑less society and inner purity; many of his verses are in Guru Granth Sahib.
morning: Morning bath; place Guru Ravidas photo; simple diya.
daytime: Read or listen to his bhajans; reflect on message of “Begampura” (city without sorrow).
mainpuja: Attend satsang at Ravidas mandir; do aarti, kirtan.
fasting-rules: No ritual fast; some devotees avoid meat, alcohol that day.
daan: Food, blankets, support for community kitchens.
notes: More a samaj/gurudwara observance; still fits “events” sheet.astroyogi​

significance: Tamil festival honoring Murugan, symbolising surrender of ego and cleansing of sins.astroyogi​
katha: Legend: Parvati gave Murugan the Vel (spear) to destroy demon Soorapadman; Thai Pusam celebrates this victory and devotees’ penance.
morning: Morning bath; wear traditional attire; set up Murugan photo if at home.
daytime: Many take kavadi vows or simple fast, chant “Om Saravanabhavaya Namah.”
mainpuja: Temple visits with milk pots, piercing rituals (where practiced), aarti and bhajan.
fasting-rules: Some keep fruits/milk fast, breaking after temple darshan.
daan: Milk, fruits, food to pilgrims and poor.
notes: Strong for South Indian audience; optional if your sheet is more North‑India focused.

muhurat: Snan & daan from sunrise; moonrise puja
significance: Culmination of Magh snan period; very auspicious for river baths, Satyanarayan puja, and charity.panchang+1
katha: Puranas describe that Magh month snan and daan free even heavy sins; Magha Purnima marks closing of the special punya window.
morning: Before sunrise, bathe in river or with Ganga jal; wear clean clothes; sankalpa for snan‑daan.
daytime: Keep partial fast or simple satvik food; chant Vishnu Sahasranama, do japa.
mainpuja: Perform Satyanarayan puja or Vishnu aarti in evening; offer kheer, fruits, tulsi; charity at riverbanks/temples.
fasting-rules: Fast can be till evening puja and then broken after moonrise with prasad and light food.
daan: Food, blankets, sesame, grains, ghee.
notes: Major day at Prayagraj Magh Mela; mark as big festival.

english-name: (Alt. calendar) Magh Purnima / Chandra Grahan – if using that source
katha: Some panchangs place Magha Purnima on 3 Feb with a lunar eclipse (Chandra Grahan); if you adopt that, add a separate row: eclipse fasting, no cooking during grahan, snan‑daan after moksha of grahan.panchang​

significance: Marks the Sun’s transit into Aquarius; auspicious for charity, Surya worship, and spiritual reflection.panchang​
katha: Puranas describe each solar ingress as opening specific punya channels; in Kumbha, focus is on cleansing and service (linked to Kumbh Mela concept).
morning: Morning bath; offer arghya to Sun with “Om Ghrini Suryaya Namah.”
daytime: Decide a charitable sankalpa (monthly donation, annadaan etc.); keep diet satvik.
mainpuja: Simple evening deepa to Surya or at home altar; brief aarti.
fasting-rules: No fast required; some choose half‑day upvas or avoid non‑veg and alcohol.
daan: Food, blankets, sesame, copper vessels.
notes: If you’re already listing Sankrantis separately, include as a row.

significance: Monthly Ganesha fast for removal of obstacles, success in exams/business, and mental clarity.panchang​
katha: Katha often narrates a king/household freed from dire problems after observing Sankashti and listening to the vrat story exactly on Chaturthi night.
morning: Pre‑dawn bath, clean altar; install Ganesha murti; take sankalpa to fast till Moonrise.
daytime: Nirjal or phalahar fast; japa of “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah;” reading Ganesh Atharvashirsha.
mainpuja: In evening, perform full Ganesha puja: durva, red flowers, modak; listen to Sankashti katha; aarti; then see Moon, offer arghya.
fasting-rules: Fast broken only after Moon darshan and offering to Ganesha; start with small piece of prasad then simple food.
daan: Modak, laddoo, fruits; donations for students/books.
notes: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times.

english-name: Amla Navami / Bhishma Ashtami (per Panchang.org description)
significance: Day for worshipping Amla tree for health and purity, and remembering Bhishma Pitamah’s teachings; promotes longevity and dharma.panchang​
katha: Texts say Amla embodies Vishnu’s presence, and eating it grants purity; Bhishma is remembered for his wisdom on Rajdharma given while on arrow bed.
morning: Morning bath; go near Amla tree (or keep Amla fruits on plate); remember Bhishma as well.
daytime: Circumambulate Amla tree, offer water, kumkum, rice; eat Amla with mantra; read Vishnu Sahasranama or portion of Mahabharata.
mainpuja: Evening aarti to Vishnu/Bhishma memory at home.
fasting-rules: Optional fast till midday or evening; break with Amla and satvik food.
daan: Amla, food, blankets to poor, especially elderly.
notes: Calendars differ whether “Bhishma Ashtami” is this or Jan; you may cross‑ref with your Jan row.

significance: One of the most powerful Ekadashis, said to free from great sins, fear, and ghostly influence, granting victory in this and next life.radhakrishnatemple+1
katha: Katha: Malyavan Gandharva and Malini apsara offended Indra; cursed as ghosts, they later observed Jaya Ekadashi fast unintentionally and were liberated, regaining divine forms.
morning: Early bath, install Vishnu image; sankalpa to observe full Jaya Ekadashi vrat.
daytime: Strictly avoid grains and intoxicants; live on fruits, milk, or if strong, water only; chant Vishnu Sahasranama, read Ekadashi katha.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja or Satyanarayan katha; offer fruits, tulsi, sweets; aarti.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi next morning after sunrise and puja; start with water‑tulsi, then light food.
daan: Food, grains, blankets, sesame to Brahmins and poor.

notes:
“ॐ नमः शिवाय” as many malas as possible.

“ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे सुगन्धिं पुष्टिवर्धनम्…” 108 times.

significance: Monday Pradosh + close to Maha Shivratri fortnight; great for mental peace, family harmony, and blessings from Shiva‑Parvati.radhakrishnatemple+1
katha: Story relates Devas and humans praying to Shiva on Trayodashi evening to be freed from sins; doing so on Monday (Shiva’s day) is said to be doubly potent.
morning: Morning snan, white clothes; vow for Soma Pradosh fast.
daytime: Phalahar or nirjal fast; Shiva nama‑japa, read Shiv Chalisa.
mainpuja: Full Pradosh puja to Shivalinga in Pradosh Kaal: abhishek, bilva leaves, dhoop‑deep, mantra japa, aarti.
fasting-rules: Break fast after Pradosh puja and naivedya; keep food light, salt‑moderate.
daan: Milk, rice, curd, white sweets.
notes: ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108; “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108.

significance: Monthly “small Shivaratri”; this one is just before Maha Shivratri, extremely good for inner purification, devotion, and overcoming tamas.panchang​
katha: Associated with the night Shiva appeared as infinite pillar of light; each month’s Chaturdashi night recapitulates opportunity for deep Shiva meditation.
morning: Morning bath; decide nirjal or phalahar fast; set Shivaling or Shiva image.
daytime: Through day keep upvas, chant “Om Namah Shivaya,” avoid negative speech, keep mind inward.
mainpuja: At night, ideally four‑prahar puja: repeat abhishekam with water, milk, honey, bilva; recite Mahamrityunjaya Mantra and Shiv Chalisa; do aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast usually nirjal till next morning; Parana after dawn Shiva puja and water‑offering to Sun.
daan: Milk, bel leaves, blankets, food to poor.
notes: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” many malas; Mahamrityunjaya 108

muhurat: Snan‑daan from sunrise; pitru rites morning
significance: New moon day focusing on pitru tarpan, karma cleansing, and preparation for Phalguna month.panchang​
katha: Puranas say Amavasya is important for ancestors; performing tarpan grants them peace and returns blessings of protection and stability.
morning: Early bath (preferably in river); arrange tarpan setup with water, black sesame, darbha.
daytime: Perform pitru tarpan with priest or via simple guided mantras; keep mind prayerful; maintain simple diet.
mainpuja: Evening deepa and small aarti at home; avoid loud celebrations.
fasting-rules: Some keep upvas or only one satvik meal after tarpan; avoid onion, garlic, alcohol.
daan: Sesame, food, clothes to poor; feeding cows, birds.
notes: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” 108; “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108.​

significance: Start of Phalguna month in Amanta (South) system; sets tone for upcoming Holi/Chaitra cycle later.panchang​
katha: Considered auspicious start for Vratas that culminate around Holi; good time to revise sadhana goals.
morning: Morning snan; mentally note new lunar month; brief puja to family deities.
daytime: Plan any month‑long vows (e.g., Monday fasts, extra japa).
mainpuja: Simple diya and aarti in evening.
fasting-rules: No fast specifically linked; optional.
daan: Any small charity, e.g., food to a poor person.
notes: Add for completeness if you’re mixing Purnimanta (North) & Amanta.

tithi-month: Phalguna Krishna Chaturthi (or Shukla by some lists)
significance: Monthly Chaturthi fast for success in new ventures, study, finances, and removal of vighnas.panchang​
katha: Generic Chaturthi katha tells of a king whose kingdom suffered constant obstacles till he honored Ganesha on Chaturthi; prosperity then returned.
morning: Morning bath; set Ganesha murti; resolve to fast till Moonrise.
daytime: Nirjal/fruit fast, Ganesh mantra japa, reading Ganesh Atharvashirsha.
mainpuja: Evening puja: offer durva, red flowers, modak; read Vinayaka Chaturthi vrat katha; aarti; then Moon darshan and arghya.
fasting-rules: Break fast after offering to Moon and Ganesha; small prasad first, then light meal.
daan: Modak, fruits, stationery for students.
notes: Use this as general masik Ganesh Chaturthi template.

tithi-month: Magha Shukla Saptami (some lists place in Feb; Panchang.org explicitly mentions 27 Feb)
significance: Sun’s chariot turning towards northern hemisphere; Surya Jayanti in some traditions; great for health, vitality.panchang​
katha: King Yashovarma’s ill son cured by Ratha Saptami vrata following sage’s advice; Surya pleased and gave him long life.
morning: Early snan with 7 arka leaves placed on body; wear clean clothes.
daytime: Offer arghya to Sun 7 times, circumambulate symbolic chariot (rangoli drawing); chant Surya mantras/Aditya Hridayam.
mainpuja: Evening diya and aarti to Surya or at home altar.
fasting-rules: Partial fast till noon or sunset common; break with wheat‑based satvik food.
daan: Wheat, jaggery, arka leaves, copper pots, eye‑care donations.
notes: In your January sheet you already have Ratha Saptami dated 25 Jan; choose one primary calendar and note alternative date here in Notes if needed.panchang​

tithi-month: Magha Shukla Ekadashi (Purnimanta reckoning – some sources)
significance: Ekadashi dedicated to remembering Bhishma & Vishnu Sahasranama teachings; observed for steadfastness and knowledge.panchang​
katha: Mahabharata narrates Bhishma’s teachings to Yudhishthira on dharma and recitation of Vishnu Sahasranama; this Ekadashi honors that transmission.
morning: Morning snan; place Vishnu and Bhishma image; sankalpa for Ekadashi fast.
daytime: As Ekadashi norms: no grains, onion, garlic, meat; chant Vishnu Sahasranama, read Mahabharata section.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja; tulsi‑archana, aarti, katha.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi next morning with proper timing; start with water‑tulsi.
daan: Food, grains, blankets, donations in memory of elders.
notes: Some calendars already had Bhishma Ekadashi/Dwadashi in Jan; treat this as alternate if you follow that panchang.

muhurat: Evening muhurat (Pradosh–late night per panchang) panchang.astrosage​
significance: Bonfire ritual symbolising victory of devotion over ego and evil, performed on Purnima night before Holi.panchang+1
katha: Demon king Hiranyakashipu’s sister Holika had boon against fire; she sat with devotee Prahlad in flames, but Holika was burnt and Prahlad saved by Vishnu’s grace.
morning: Morning snan; clean home; set up small Holika spot with cow dung cakes, sticks.
daytime: Prepare offerings: grains, coconuts, sweets; keep mind on letting go of negativities.
mainpuja: In muhurat, perform Holika puja (rakhi tying, circumambulation), then light pyre; throw offerings, chant bhajans; symbolically cast bad habits into fire.
fasting-rules: No strict fast; some keep light diet until Holika is burnt; children enjoy snacks afterwards.
daan: Grains, sweets, clothes to poor children.
notes: “ॐ नरसिंहाय नमः” 108 (if you emphasise Nrisimha aspect) or simple “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108.

tithi-month: Phalguna Shukla Pratipada (or Purnima by some)
significance: Festival of colors, joy, and social harmony, marking end of winter and victory of good over evil.panchang+1
katha: Linked to Prahlad story; in Braj, associated with Krishna’s leelas of playing colors with Gopis and Radha, expressing divine love.
morning: Morning snan; apply tilak; do simple home puja to Krishna or Vishnu.
daytime: Play colors with organic gulal, visit friends/family; forgive past grievances; sing folk songs.
mainpuja: Evening, clean up, light diya at altar, thank God; sometimes small Lakshmi or Krishna puja.
fasting-rules: No vrat; feasting on gujiya, malpua etc.; avoid intoxication if you want sattvic observance.
daan: Food, sweets to poor, workers, and children.
notes: “हरे कृष्ण हरे कृष्ण कृष्ण कृष्ण हरे हरे, हरे राम हरे राम राम राम हरे हरे” as many rounds as you like.

significance: Monthly fast for removal of problems (sankat), success, and intellect sharpening.panchang+1
katha: Typical katha: a troubled king/household experiences repeated misfortune until a sage instructs Sankashti vrat; after sincere observance and listening to katha, all obstacles vanish.
morning: Pre‑dawn bath, clean altar; place Ganesha murti; sankalpa for nirjal or phalahar fast till Moonrise.
daytime: Japa of “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah,” reading Ganesh Atharvashirsha; avoid anger, gossip.
mainpuja: Evening puja: durva, red flowers, modak; recite Sankashti katha; aarti; Moon darshan and arghya, then naivedya.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after Moon is seen and offerings made; start with prasad then light satvik food.
daan: Modak, laddoo, fruits; support for students (books).

significance: Solar ingress into Meena (Pisces); auspicious for charity, introspection, and closing of Pisces‑year cycle.panchang​
katha: Each Sankranti marks a shift in Sun’s transit; Meena Sankranti is associated with spiritual reflection before new year (Chaitra).
morning: Morning bath; offer arghya to Sun with mantras; optional brief Vishnu puja.
daytime: Resolve to let go of past year’s negativities; plan last‑month sadhana push.
mainpuja: Evening deepa and aarti to Surya/Vishnu at home altar.
fasting-rules: No fixed fast; many simply avoid non‑veg and intoxicants.
daan: Food, sesame, clothes, copper vessels.
notes: Mark this as “Festival/Other” depending on your categorisation.

significance: Ekadashi that destroys accumulated sins (paap‑mochani) and tendencies toward harmful actions.panchang+1
katha: Story: Sage Medhavi was seduced by divine nymph Manjughosha and fell from tapas; later, on guidance, he observed Papmochani Ekadashi, regaining purity and spiritual status.
morning: Early snan; install Vishnu image; sankalpa for Papmochani Ekadashi fast.
daytime: Follow strict Ekadashi rules: no grains, avoid tamasic food; chant Vishnu Sahasranama, do katha reading.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja/Satyanarayan; offer fruits, tulsi; aarti; meditate on giving up specific vices.
fasting-rules: Fast until Dwadashi Parana next morning; break with water‑tulsi, then light food.
daan: Food, grains, blankets, sesame, support to those trying to leave addictions.
notes: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” or “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108/1008

significance: Saturday Pradosh especially for relief from Shani dosha, debts, court cases, and karmic burdens.panchang+1
katha: Legend: A devotee suffering under Saturn’s influence prayed to Shiva during Shani Pradosh; Shiva, pleased, lessened his suffering and granted steady progress.
morning: Morning bath; optionally light sesame oil lamp for Shani; sankalpa for fast.
daytime: Fast with fruits/milk; chant “Om Namah Shivaya” and Shani mantra “Om Sham Shanicharaya Namah.”
mainpuja: In Pradosh Kaal, abhishek to Shivalinga, offer black sesame, oil diya; bilva leaves; Mahamrityunjaya japa; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast concludes after Pradosh puja; food should be simple and satvik.
daan: Black sesame, oil, blankets, food to poor and to workers.
notes: Mark as Shani Pradosh explicitly; high interest for many sadhaks.

significance: Monthly Shivratri; this one bridges into end of Phalguna and prepares mind for upcoming Chaitra Navratri.panchang+1
katha: Same Shiva infinite‑pillar story; all monthly Shivratris remember his formless jyoti‑svarupa, encouraging deep meditation.
morning: Morning snan; vow for upvas; arrange Shivalinga.
daytime: Fast on water/milk or fruits; do regular japa, read Shiva Purana stories.
mainpuja: Four‑prahar night puja: repeat abhishek with water, milk, honey, etc.; bilva‑puja; chant “Om Namah Shivaya” and Mahamrityunjaya; aarti.
fasting-rules: Parana next morning after dawn Shiva puja and offering water to Surya.
daan: Milk, bel leaves, ghee, blankets, food.
notes: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” many malas; Mahamrityunjaya 108.

significance: New moon day for ancestral rites, spiritual cleansing, and end of Phalguna in Amanta system.panchang​
katha: Similar to other Amavasya legends: performing tarpan and charity pleases Pitru and removes obstacles.
morning: Early snan in river/with Ganga jal; arrange tarpan items.
daytime: Perform pitru tarpan with priest or standard mantras; maintain quiet, reflective mood.
mainpuja: Evening lamp and brief home puja; avoid heavy entertainment.
fasting-rules: Optional fast or single satvik meal; avoid onion, garlic, alcohol.
daan: Food, rice, sesame, clothes to poor and Brahmins.
notes: In Purnimanta North, this may be listed differently; note both systems in “Notes.”

significance: In South/Amanta system, this Purnima is key for Holi‑type festivities and charity, though many celebrate Holi on North dates.panchang​
katha: Similar to other Purnima legends: Vishnu’s grace most accessible; Satyanarayan katha especially recommended for prosperity and resolution of issues.
morning: Morning bath; sankalpa for Purnima vrat; set Vishnu/Satyanarayan image.
daytime: Partial fast or simple diet; chant Vishnu Sahasranama; read or hear katha.
mainpuja: Evening Satyanarayan puja with five fruits, wheat flour halwa, tulsi; aarti; prasad distribution.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after katha and aarti with prasad; then light meal.
daan: Grains, sweets, clothes to poor.
notes: Keep this if you track both North & South observances.

significance: Start of Chaitra month in North (Purnimanta), considered as beginning of Hindu Vikram Samvat cycle preparation.panchang​
katha: Chaitra linked with spring, renewal; many calendars treat next Shukla Pratipada as New Year (Gudi Padwa/Ugadi).
morning: Morning snan; simple home puja; mentally acknowledge new month.
daytime: Plan Navratri/ New Year vows; organise cleaning of house and altar.
mainpuja: Evening diya and aarti.
fasting-rules: No fast; optional simple diet.
daan: Any small charity; start monthly annadaan if possible.
notes: Use “Type = Other” as it is more structural/calendar note.

significance: New Year in Maharashtra (Gudi Padwa) and Andhra–Karnataka (Ugadi); new cycle of time, fresh karmic beginning.panchang​
katha: Scriptures say Brahma began creation on this day; people hoist Gudi (victory flag) or draw Ugadi rangoli, symbolising triumph and prosperity.
morning: Morning snan, wear new/clean clothes; prepare Gudi (kalash, cloth, neem‑mango leaves) in Maharashtra or Ugadi toran/rangoli in South.
daytime: Panchang shravanam (almanac reading) by priest, eating neem‑jaggery mixture symbolising acceptance of sweet‑bitter in life.
mainpuja: Home Lakshmi‑Narayana or Kuladevata puja; aarti; feast with traditional dishes (puran poli, obbattu, pachadi).
fasting-rules: No fast; rather celebratory feast, though satvik.
daan: Food, clothes, donations for education.
notes: Very important festival: mark as “Festival” with New Year note.

tithi-month: Chaitra Shukla Pratipada (some lists show 19; aligning to AstroSage date 19 or Panchang.org 25 – choose one and note alternate) panchang+1
significance: Nine‑day Navratri for Devi worship, inner purification, and start of Hindu New Year in North.panchang+1
katha: Legends recount Durga’s nine forms defeating Mahishasura and other demons; each day honors one form, leading to victory over inner negativity.
morning: Morning snan; perform Ghatasthapana: install Kalash with mango leaves and coconut, Durga image; take 9‑day vrat sankalpa.
daytime: Daily partial fast (one meal or fruits/milk), Durga Saptashati reading, japa of “Ya Devi Sarvabhuteshu.”
mainpuja: Evening aarti and bhajans to Durga; kumkum tilak to women and girls.
fasting-rules: Fast pattern continues till Navami or Ashtami; some break on Ashtami with Kanya puja, others on Navami.
daan: Food, fruits, clothes to Kanya (little girls), distribution of prasad.
notes:
Standard Navratri mantra set per day:

Day 1 Shailaputri – “ॐ देवी शैलपुत्र्यै नमः” 108.

Day 2 Brahmacharini – “ॐ देवी ब्रह्मचारिण्यै नमः” 108.

Day 3 Chandraghanta – “ॐ देवी चन्द्रघंटायै नमः” 108.

Day 4 Kushmanda – “ॐ देवी कूष्मांडायै नमः” 108.

Day 5 Skandamata – “ॐ देवी स्कन्दमातायै नमः” 108.

Day 6 Katyayani – “ॐ देवी कात्यायन्यै नमः” 108.

Day 7 Kalaratri – “ॐ देवी कालरात्र्यै नमः” 108.

Day 8 Mahagauri – “ॐ देवी महागौर्यै नमः” 108.

Day 9 Siddhidatri – “ॐ देवी सिद्धिदात्र्यै नमः” 108.

For Murugan: “ॐ सरवनभवाय नमः” 108.

For divine couples (Rama–Sita, Shiva–Parvati): “सीताराम” japa or “ॐ गौरी शंकराय नमः” 108.

significance: Birthday of Lord Rama, symbol of dharma, ideal son/king; observed for virtue, peace, and family harmony.panchang​
katha: Rama born in Ayodhya to Dasharatha and Kaushalya; his life in Ramayana exemplifies righteousness and devotion, guided by Vishnu’s avataric purpose.
morning: Early snan; clean altar; install Ram‑Sita‑Lakshman‑Hanuman images; sankalpa for fast.
daytime: Upvas or fruits/milk till mid‑day; Ramayan or Ramcharitmanas reading; “Shri Ram Jai Ram Jai Jai Ram” japa.
mainpuja: At Madhyahna, perform Ram Janma puja: bathe Rama idol, decorate cradle, sing birth kirtans; aarti; distribute panjiri/prasad.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after mid‑day puja with prasad and then proper satvik food; some keep fast till evening aarti.
daan: Food, clothes, books (Ramayana) to devotees/poor children.
notes:
“श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम” 108/1008 times.

Or simple “राम” nama‑japa many times.

muhurat: Morning–midday puja; Kanya pujan usually late morning panchang​
significance: Eighth day of Chaitra Navratri; worship of Mahagauri for purity, marital happiness, and removal of inner impurities.panchang​
katha: Katha describes Devi as Mahagauri, who did tapas to win Shiva; her severe penance whitened her form, symbolizing purified consciousness.
morning: Snan; install Durga/Mahagauri image; take Ashtami vrat sankalpa if keeping full Navratri fast.
daytime: Continue Navratri fast (one meal, fruits, or only water) with recitation of Durga Saptashati/Kavach.
mainpuja: Perform Kumari/Kanya pujan: wash girls’ feet, apply kumkum, offer food and gifts; Durga aarti and bhajans.
fasting-rules: If you break on Ashtami, do so after Kanya pujan with prasad and satvik bhojan; otherwise continue to Navami.
daan: Food, clothes, bangles, fruits to girls and women.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ देवी महागौर्यै नमः” 108 times.

significance: Celebrates birth of Lord Rama; brings dharma, peace at home, and strength to walk righteous path.panchang​
katha: Ayodhya’s King Dasharatha, after yagna, was blessed with Rama; his life in Ramayana shows ideal sonhood, kingship, and devotion to Vishnu’s will.
morning: Early snan; decorate altar with Ram‑Sita‑Lakshman‑Hanuman images; vow for fast if health permits.
daytime: Read Ramayana/Ramcharitmanas, chant “Shri Ram Jai Ram Jai Jai Ram;” keep phalahar or nirjal until mid‑day puja.
mainpuja: At Madhyahna, do abhishek of Rama murti, cradle (jhula) puja, sing janmotsav bhajans, perform aarti, distribute panjiri/panjiri‑like prasad.
fasting-rules: Break fast after mid‑day puja with prasad and satvik food; some keep fast till evening aarti.
daan: Food, sweets, copies of Ramayana to children/temples.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम” minimum 108 times.

significance: Completion of 9‑day Navratri; formal ending of vrat with Kanya puja and havan for fulfilling desires and protection.
katha: Devi pleased after nine days of worship grants boons; tradition says Kanya are forms of Durga, so feeding them completes the vrat.
morning: Morning snan; prepare Kanya pujan items (flowers, food, gifts); set havan kund if doing homa.
daytime: Perform Kanya puja, feed girls and at least one boy as Bhairav; offer dakshina.
mainpuja: Conduct brief havan with Durga mantras; final aarti, distribute prasad.
fasting-rules: Vrat ends with Parana after rituals; eat satvik food, avoiding onion/garlic that day.
daan: Food, clothes, sweets to Kanya, Brahmins, poor.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108 times during homa/puja.

significance: Ekadashi famous for destroying accumulated sins, addictions, and negative tendencies; powerful for sadhaks.panchang​
katha: Sage Medhavi, seduced by apsara Manjughosha, lost his tapasya; later observed Papmochani Ekadashi on advice and regained purity and spiritual status.
morning: Early bath; install Vishnu image; sankalpa for strict Ekadashi fast.
daytime: Avoid grains, onion/garlic; keep fruits, milk, or water‑only fast; recite Vishnu Sahasranama and Papmochani katha.
mainpuja: In evening, perform Vishnu or Satyanarayan puja; tulsi‑archana, aarti, bhajan.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi after sunrise and Vishnu puja; break with water‑tulsi then light satvik meal.
daan: Food, grains, blankets, sesame; support to those trying to quit bad habits.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108 or 1008 times.

significance: Monday Pradosh is highly auspicious for marital harmony, peace of mind, and Shiva‑Shakti grace.panchang​
katha: Devas worshipped Shiva in Pradosh to overcome suffering; on Monday, associated with Somnath and Chandrama on Shiva’s head, mind becomes calm and clear.
morning: Morning snan; wear white/light clothes; vow to keep fast till Pradosh puja.
daytime: Phalahar or nirjal; japa of “Om Namah Shivaya,” read Shiv Chalisa.
mainpuja: In Pradosh Kaal, do abhishek of Shivalinga (water, milk, curd, honey, ghee); offer bilva, dhoop‑deep; chant Mahamrityunjaya; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after Pradosh puja; eat simple satvik food after offering to Shiva.
daan: Milk, curd, rice, white sweets, bel leaves to temple/poor.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” (108/5 mala) or “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे …” 108 times.

significance: Monthly Shivratri; this one falls in Chaitra Krishna, ideal for deep meditation, breaking old patterns, and invoking Shiva’s formless jyoti.panchang​
katha: Story of Shiva as endless pillar of light; Brahma and Vishnu failed to find beginning or end, teaching humility before the Absolute.
morning: Morning bath; promise nirjal or phalahar fast; set up Shivalinga.
daytime: Continue upvas; chant “Om Namah Shivaya,” read Shiva Purana stories; avoid tamasic impressions.
mainpuja: Night puja in 1–4 prahars: repeated abhishek, bilva, dhatura (if traditional), incense, lamp; long japa and meditation; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast typically continues till next morning; Parana after dawn puja and Surya arghya.
daan: Milk, bel leaves, ghee, food, blankets.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” continuously; target at least 5–11 malas overnight.

muhurat: Snan‑daan in morning; pitru tarpan during forenoon panchang​
significance: Powerful Amavasya for pitru tarpan, removing ancestral doshas, and preparing for New Year the next day.panchang​
katha: Puranas say Amavasya tarpan quenches Pitru hunger; Chaitra Amavasya especially helps clear karmic blocks before New Year begins.
morning: Early holy bath (river/Ganga jal); arrange tarpan tray with water, black sesame, darbha.
daytime: Perform pitru tarpan with priest or standard mantras; keep mind humble and grateful; maintain sattvic diet.
mainpuja: Simple deepa and family aarti in evening; avoid major celebrations.
fasting-rules: Some keep fast or one‑meal satvik diet; break post‑noon or evening after tarpan/daan.
daan: Sesame, food, clothes, feed cows/dogs/crows.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” during tarpan; Gayatri japa for self‑purification.

english-name: Chaitra Shukla Pratipada – Hindu New Year (North/Vikram Samvat 2083)
hindi-name: चैत्र शुक्ल प्रतिपदा – विक्रम संवत नववर्ष
significance: Traditional New Year day for North India (Vikram Samvat 2083); excellent for new sankalpas, business books opening, and home puja.panchang​
katha: Brahma is said to have begun creation this day; kings historically used this tithi to start regnal years; very auspicious for starting projects.
morning: Morning snan; decorate doorway with toran, draw rangoli; place kalash and deities at altar.
daytime: Do Panchang shravan (if available), set spiritual/financial goals; eat neem‑jaggery mixture symbolising acceptance of life’s dualities.
mainpuja: Perform Lakshmi‑Narayana or Kuladevata puja; aarti; family satsang; start new account books (मुहूर्त for business).
fasting-rules: No fast; celebratory satvik meals; avoid quarrels and negativity today.
daan: Food, clothes, books, donations for education.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” and “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय,” 108 each.

muhurat: Morning installation (Gudi / Ugadi muhurat mid‑morning) panchang​
significance: Maharashtrian Gudi Padwa and Andhra‑Karnataka Ugadi New Year celebrations, invoking victory, prosperity, and order.panchang​
katha: Gudi (flag with kalash) symbolises victory banner of Rama or Shalivahana; Ugadi legend ties to Brahma creating the world.
morning: Morning snan; for Gudi Padwa, hoist Gudi outside home; for Ugadi, decorate with mango toran and rangoli.
daytime: Prepare neem‑jaggery chutney and traditional dishes; listen to yearly Panchang reading; maintain positive mindset.
mainpuja: Home puja of Lakshmi‑Narayana or Kuladevata; aarti, sharing feast with family.
fasting-rules: No vrat; feast day but keep satvik; some avoid onion/garlic.
daan: Food, clothes, grains; donations supporting students/temples.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” and simple “ॐ श्री रामाय नमः” (esp. if tying Gudi as Rama’s flag).

significance: Monthly Ganesh Chaturthi fast for success, prosperity, and obstacle‑removal in new year projects.panchang​
katha: Similar to main Chaturthi legend: once Moon mocked Ganesha; cursed, he lost his glory but regained it by Chaturthi vrat; shows how humility + devotion restore fortune.
morning: Pre‑dawn bath; set Ganesha murti; sankalpa for upvas till Moonrise.
daytime: Japa of “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah;” prepare modak, laddoo, durva; perform light altar cleaning.
mainpuja: Evening puja: abhishek (milk/water), durva, red flowers; Vinayaka Chaturthi katha, aarti; Moon darshan and arghya afterwards.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after Moon and Ganesha are offered water and naivedya; then light satvik meal.
daan: Modak, laddoo, fruits; notebooks/pens for children.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108 or 1008 times.

tithi-month: Chaitra Shukla Tritiya (or around this period) panchang​
significance: Popular in Rajasthan and some North regions; married and unmarried women worship Gauri for marital bliss and ideal husband.
katha: Story: Parvati as Gauri visited her parental home and then returned to Shiva; women send off Gauri with songs, seeking her blessings for their marital life.
morning: Morning bath; women draw images of Gauri–Shiva or use clay/wooden idols; wear traditional attire.
daytime: Fasts by women (often on water or fruits) till puja; sing Gangaur songs while preparing puja.
mainpuja: Puja with kumkum, mehendi, bangles, sweets; small procession/visarjan of Gauri idol in water/river later.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja and immersion; prasad and family meal.
daan: Bangles, mehendi, cosmetics, clothes to married women and girls.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ गौरी शंकराय नमः” or “ॐ पार्वत्यै नमः” 108 times.

significance: Solar New Year: Baisakhi (Punjab), Tamil Puthandu (TN), Pohela Boishakh (Bengal often 15th); linked to harvest, Khalsa founding, and new year accounts.panchang​
katha: For Sikhs, Baisakhi commemorates 1699 Khalsa initiation; for Tamil, it’s start of new year month Chithirai; Sun in Aries is exalted, bringing energy and growth.
morning: Early bath; Sun arghya; wear new/clean clothes; decorate house.
daytime: Visit Gurudwara/temple; start new account books; attend fairs; in Tamil homes, keep Vishu kani‑like arrangement (in TN Puthandu).
mainpuja: Evening bhajans, kirtans, or Gurudwara kirtan; diya lighting at home altar.
fasting-rules: No fast; abundant feast but keep rajasic excess limited if you want spiritual tone.
daan: Food, clothes, grains; support to farmers, Gurudwaras/temples.
notes: Mantra‑japa: Surya – “ॐ घृणि: सू्र्याय नमः” 108 times.

muhurat: Morning (Vishu kani / new year darshan) panchang​
significance: Bengali Pohela Boishakh & Kerala’s Vishu mark regional New Year, emphasising good beginnings, prosperity, and darshan at dawn.panchang​
katha: For Vishu, the legend emphasises first sight of auspicious items (kani) bringing year‑long prosperity; for Pohela Boishakh, it’s linked to Akbar’s revenue reforms and local harvest.
morning: Before sunrise, prepare Vishu kani (lamp, rice, fruits, gold) or Bengali new year altar with Kalash and images.
daytime: At dawn, open eyes to kani/altar; then temple visit; plan new‑year resolutions and house cleaning.
mainpuja: Evening puja to Vishnu/Krishna with aarti; family feast and cultural programmes.
fasting-rules: No fast; focus on festive satvik food.
daan: Food, clothes, contributions to cultural/temple trusts.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नारायणाय विद्महे वासुदेवाय धीमहि तन्नो विष्णुः प्रचोदयात्” (Vishnu Gayatri) 11–27 times.

tithi-month: Vaishakha Krishna Ekadashi (or end‑Chaitra depending system) panchang​
significance: Ekadashi believed to grant good fortune, protection from misfortune (varuthini = protected), and prosperity.panchang​
katha: Katha speaks of a king Mandhata who lost his limbs due to sin; by observing Varuthini Ekadashi, he regained auspiciousness and freedom from suffering.
morning: Early snan; vow Ekadashi fast; worship Vishnu.
daytime: Avoid grains, onion, garlic; japa of Vishnu Sahasranama; read Varuthini Ekadashi katha.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja; tulsi‑archana, aarti, bhajan.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi with proper timing and charity; break with tulsi water and light food.
daan: Food, grains, sesame, charity to physically challenged and poor.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 or more.

tithi-month: Vaishakha Shukla Trayodashi (or Chaitra per system) panchang​
significance: Saturday Pradosh again, now in next fortnight; emphasises relief from karmic blocks, court cases, job stagnation.panchang​
katha: Many katha variants show devotees freed from imprisonment, poverty, and Shani’s harsh gaze by sincere Shani Pradosh fast and Shiva worship.
morning: Morning bath; light sesame oil lamp for Shani; vow for Shani‑Pradosh fast.
daytime: Fast with fruits/milk; do combined japa of “Om Namah Shivaya” and “Om Sham Shanicharaya Namah.”
mainpuja: Pradosh puja to Shivalinga with Panchamrit; offer black sesame, oil diya; chant Mahamrityunjaya; aarti.
fasting-rules: Break fast after Pradosh puja with light, non‑spicy food.
daan: Black sesame, mustard oil, blankets, food to poor, especially workers.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” + “ॐ शं शनैश्चराय नमः,” at least 108 each.

muhurat: Morning–midday or evening, depending local tradition
significance: Celebrates birth of Hanuman, symbol of strength, devotion to Rama, and removal of fear and black magic.panchang+1
katha: Puranic story: Anjana gave birth to Hanuman by divine grace; as child he tried to eat the Sun; later became Rama’s greatest devotee, epitome of seva and brahmacharya.
morning: Morning snan; wear red/orange clothes; install Hanuman photo/idol; sankalpa for fast if possible.
daytime: Fast on fruits/boiled chana; continuous Hanuman Chalisa recitation, Bajrang Baan/Sunderkand paath; offer sindoor mixed with oil.
mainpuja: Main puja as per local timing: abhishek with oil/water, apply sindoor, offer boondi/laddu; sing Hanuman Chalisa, aarti, kirtans.
fasting-rules: Fast usually broken after main puja with prasad; many keep nirjal till evening or until completing Sunderkand.
daan: Boondi laddu, chana, bananas; food, blankets to poor; feeding monkeys if possible.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ हनुमते नमः” 108/1008 times; plus Hanuman Chalisa at least once.

muhurat: Snan‑daan morning; evening Satyanarayan; moonrise puja panchang​
significance: First Purnima of new year; very auspicious for charity, Satyanarayan vrat, and starting the year’s major vows.panchang​
katha: Narratives emphasise river baths and anna‑daan on Chaitra Purnima granting multiplied merit; also linked with Satyanarayan vrat katha of traders/families whose fortunes were restored.
morning: Early bath, preferably river snan; vow for Purnima fast/puja; arrange Satyanarayan setup.
daytime: Keep partial fast or satvik one‑meal; chant “Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya;” read simple Puran stories.
mainpuja: Evening Satyanarayan puja with banana, fruits, suji halwa; read katha; aarti; moonrise darshan and prasad.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja and prasad; some wait till moonrise.
daan: Food, fruits, grains, clothes to poor; feeding Brahmins/cows.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नारायणाय नमः” or “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108 times.

tithi-month: First visible crescent after Purnima (some list after Amavasya – here as per Panchang.org) panchang​
muhurat: Just after sunset, when crescent appears
significance: First sighting of Moon after its key phase; praying then is believed to bring emotional balance, peace, and steady mind.panchang​
katha: Connected to myths where Chandra, cursed for pride, sought Shiva’s refuge; balanced Moon energy stabilises mind and relationships.
morning: Morning routine; no special strictness; prepare plate with rice, milk sweet, water.
daytime: Maintain calm/dharmic thoughts; plan to step outside post‑sunset.
mainpuja: After sighting Moon, offer arghya with water, rice; chant Chandra mantra; simple aarti.
fasting-rules: No fast; some eat after Chandra Darshan in symbolic upasana.
daan: Rice, white sweets, milk to children/poor.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ चन्द्राय नमः” 11 or 27 times.

significance: Start of Vaishakha month, considered very sacred for bathing, charity, and Vishnu devotion; linked to Akshaya Tritiya period.panchang​
katha: Vaishakha is praised in scriptures as best for Ganga snan and daan; even small acts of charity are said to give lasting punya.
morning: Morning snan with Ganga jal; brief Vishnu puja; vow for increased japa and daan during Vaishakha.
daytime: Decide on small regular charity (e.g., feeding one person daily); do daily Vishnu nama‑japa.
mainpuja: Usual evening aarti at home altar.
fasting-rules: No special fast; optional Monday/Thursday or Ekadashi‑focus fasts through month.
daan: Food, water, buttermilk to travellers/poor (as heat rises).
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ विष्णवे नमः” 108 times at month start.

muhurat: Moonrise (~8 PM; check local panchang) panchang+1
significance: Another monthly Ganesha Chaturthi fast, now in Vaishakha, for obstacles removal and success in continuing New Year resolutions.panchang​
katha: Same general Chaturthi story pattern: by worshipping Ganapati on this tithi, one is shielded from future hurdles and misfortune.
morning: Pre‑dawn snan; clean altar, place Ganesh murti; vow upvas till Moonrise.
daytime: Japa of “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah;” preparation of naivedya and flowers.
mainpuja: Evening puja as earlier: abhishek, durva, red flowers, modak; katha; aarti; Moon darshan and arghya.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after offering to Moon & Ganesha; prasad eaten first, then light meal.
daan: Modak, laddoo, fruits; stationery for children.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times.

muhurat: Sunrise‑to‑sunset; whole day auspicious, no special muhurat needed panchang​
significance: One of most auspicious days of the year; any good act—daan, japa, investments—is believed to give “akshaya” (ever‑growing) punya/benefit.panchang​
katha: Legends: Krishna gave Sudama immense wealth on this day; Ganga descended; also connected to start of Treta Yuga.
morning: Early snan; white/yellow clothes; home Vishnu–Lakshmi altar; resolve for giving and sadhana.
daytime: Perform japa, annadaan, help the needy; if buying gold/property, do it prayerfully without greed.
mainpuja: Lakshmi‑Narayana or Kuber‑Lakshmi puja in evening; aarti; distribute sweets and food.
fasting-rules: You may keep light fast or normal satvik diet; focus is on charity rather than strict upvas.
daan: Food, grains, gold/ornaments donations as per capacity; water, buttermilk in heat.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” and “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108 each.

significance: Generic Krishna‑Paksha Pradosh for forgiveness of sins, stability, and Shiva’s grace.
katha: Shiva once forgave devas and asuras during Pradosh and granted them equal access to amrita; shows his impartial compassion.
morning: Morning bath; vow for Pradosh fast.
daytime: Phalahar, Shiva‑nama japa, reading Shiv Chalisa.
mainpuja: In Pradosh Kaal, full abhishek, bilva, deepa, dhoop; Mahamrityunjaya or Rudram (if possible); aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast from sunrise till after puja; break with satvik food.
daan: Milk, rice, ghee, bel leaves.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108+ times; optionally Mahamrityunjaya 108 times.

significance: Monthly Shivratri again; good for deeper tapas in rising summer, burning inner tamas.
katha: Same jyoti‑linga story; this night invites focus on inner light beyond body‑mind.
morning: Morning snan; choose nirjal/fruit fast; set Shivalinga.
daytime: Upvas, japa, reading Shiva Purana, mental mauna as much as possible.
mainpuja: Night‑long, 4‑prahar puja with abhishek, bilva, mantra; aarti; meditation.
fasting-rules: Parana next morning after dawn Shiva and Surya worship.
daan: Food, water, fast‑breaking meals for poor and sadhus.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” for bulk japa; try 11–21 malas over night if possible.

significance: Vaishakha Amavasya considered very potent for pitru tarpan and Ganga snan, washing away heavy karmic burdens.panchang​
katha: Puranas praise Vaishakha month; Amavasya shraddha here gives relief to pitru and helps descendants progress.
morning: Before sunrise, river/Ganga jal snan; arrange tarpan materials.
daytime: Perform tarpan / shraddha as per gotra with priest guidance or simple mantras; maintain satvik mind.
mainpuja: Evening deepa, Narayana puja, aarti; avoid loud entertainment.
fasting-rules: Optional fast or single satvik meal; avoid tamasic foods and intoxication.
daan: Sesame, food, clothes, cows’ fodder; feeding poor, birds, animals.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” and “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” during tarpan/japa.

muhurat: Snan‑daan morning; evening Satyanarayan; moonrise puja dharmikvibes​
significance: One of the holiest Purnimas, excellent for Ganga/river snan, Satyanarayan vrat, and big charity; Vaishakha month multiplies punya.dharmikvibes+1
katha: Texts praise Vaishakha snan and anna‑daan as equal to many yagnas; numerous Satyanarayan vrat kathas show how families’ fortunes reversed after performing this vrata.
morning: Pre‑dawn bath (river or Ganga jal); wear clean clothes; take sankalpa for Purnima vrat/Satyanarayan puja.
daytime: Partial fast or one‑meal satvik diet; Vishnu Sahasranama and japa of Vishnu mantra; prepare puja items.
mainpuja: In evening, do Satyanarayan puja: kalash, pancha phal, suji halwa, panchamrit; read full katha; aarti; moonrise darshan and prasad.
fasting-rules: Break fast after puja and prasad (some after moonrise); keep food simple and satvik.
daan: Food, grains, sweets, clothes; feeding Brahmins, cows, poor.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108/1008 times.

significance: Marks birth, enlightenment, and Mahaparinirvana of Gautama Buddha; important for ahimsa, meditation, and compassion.dharmikvibes​
katha: Stories recount Siddhartha’s birth in Lumbini, enlightenment under Bodhi tree at Bodh Gaya, and teaching Middle Path; Vesak compresses his key life events in symbolic remembrance.
morning: Morning snan; keep space clean and quiet; optionally set Buddha statue or picture.
daytime: Practice mauna (reduced talk), metta (loving‑kindness) meditation, read Dhammapada; avoid violence/harshness.
mainpuja: Attend temple/vihara if possible; offer flowers, incense, lamps; listen to discourses; do silent prayer for all beings.
fasting-rules: Light, mostly vegetarian diet; some observe fast till evening meditation/visit.
daan: Food, fruits, robes/support to monks; donations to charities.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “बुद्धं शरणं गच्छामि, धम्मं शरणं गच्छामि, संघं शरणं गच्छामि” (3 refuges, repeated).

english-name: Narada Jayanti (tithi falls just after Vaishakh Purnima)
significance: Birth jayanti of sage Narada, symbol of bhakti, kirtan, and divine message‑bringing.dharmikvibes​
katha: Narada appears across Puranas carrying news between worlds, inspiring devotion and sometimes creating situations to reveal the Lord’s glory.
morning: Morning snan; place small Narada picture or simply Vishnu/Krishna image.
daytime: Read or listen to Narada Bhakti Sutra or stories of Narada in Bhagavatam.
mainpuja: Simple aarti to Vishnu/Krishna, with remembrance of Narada as ideal devotee.
fasting-rules: No formal fast; optional light diet and extra bhajan/kirtan.
daan: Food, books (scripture) to seekers; small donations to kirtan/temple groups.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “नारायण नारायण” japa (very simple and Narada‑style).

tithi-month: Jyeshtha Krishna Chaturthi (per DharmikVibes list for May 5) dharmikvibes​
significance: Monthly Sankashti vrat for removing obstacles, health problems, financial and exam issues.dharmikvibes​
katha: Usual katha: a troubled king or family saved from calamity by observing this Chaturthi and hearing the story; Ganesha promises to clear sankat.
morning: Pre‑dawn bath; establish Ganesha; take sankalpa to fast till Moonrise.
daytime: Nirjal or fruit fast, japa of “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah;” study or recite Ganesh Atharvashirsha.
mainpuja: Evening puja: abhishek with water/milk, offer durva, red flowers, modak; read Sankashti katha; aarti; Moon darshan and arghya.
fasting-rules: Fast broken only after seeing Moon and offering water and naivedya to Moon and Ganesha.
daan: Modak, laddoo, fruits; support for students (books, fees).
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times.

significance: Known as “Apara” (limitless) Ekadashi, believed to destroy heavy sins and give great spiritual and material merit.guptvrindavandham​
katha: Katha mentions King Mahidhvaja, a merchant, and a sinful Brahmin whose destinies changed by Apara Ekadashi; even minor observance yields huge punya.
morning: Morning snan; install Vishnu image; resolve for strict Ekadashi fast.
daytime: No grains, onion, garlic; perform Vishnu Sahasranama japa, listen to Apara Ekadashi katha; remain humble and truthful.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu/Satyanarayan puja with tulsi‑archana, aarti; satsang if possible.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi after sunrise and Vishnu puja; break with tulsi water and light food.
daan: Food, grains, sesame, clothes to poor, Brahmins.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” or “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108+ times.

significance: Generic Krishna Pradosh, good for forgiveness of sins, inner strength, recovery from difficulties.dharmikvibes​
