katha: As with all Pradosh, devas and humans sought Shiva’s help at this twilight; he danced divine Tandava removing their miseries.
morning: Early snan; sankalpa for Pradosh fast; Shivalinga installation.
daytime: Fast with fruits/milk; repeat “Om Namah Shivaya;” read Shiv Chalisa and small portion of Shiva Purana.
mainpuja: In Pradosh Kaal, abhishek with water, milk, curd, honey, ghee; bilva‑archana, dhoop‑deep, Mahamrityunjaya japa; aarti.
fasting-rules: Break fast after puja with light satvik meal, having first offered naivedya to Shiva.
daan: Milk, curd, rice, white sweets; bel leaves to temple.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” and “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108 times.

significance: Monthly Shivratri in Jyeshtha, helpful for burning strong vasanas (summer heat mirrors inner tapas).
katha: Same jyotirlinga pillar of light story; emphasises worship of Shiva beyond form.
morning: Morning bath; vow for nirjal or fruit‑only fast; Shivaling set up.
daytime: Maintain upvas; focus on “Om Namah Shivaya” japa, avoid anger, gossip; read stories of Shiva’s compassion.
mainpuja: Night‑long 4‑prahar puja: repeated abhishek, bilva, incense, lamp; long japa; meditation; aarti in each prahar if possible.
fasting-rules: Parana next morning after dawn Shiva & Surya worship; break with water, then light food.
daan: Food, water, buttermilk to poor and sadhus in heat.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 11–21 malas; add Mahamrityunjaya 108 times if able.

significance: Sun’s transit into Taurus; favours stability, finance, and agricultural planning, good for daan.
katha: Each Sankranti is a mini gateway; Vrishabha Sankranti linked with steadiness, wealth, and nourishment (Taurus qualities).
morning: Morning snan; offer arghya to Sun with mantra; pray for stable finances and health.
daytime: Plan or review budget and saving/investment discipline; do small charity.
mainpuja: Evening diya and short Surya/Lakshmi aarti.
fasting-rules: No specified fast; optional light diet, avoiding rajasic foods.
daan: Food, ghee, grains, support to farmers and cows.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ घृणि सू्र्याय नमः” 108 times; optionally “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः.”

significance: New moon during intensifying heat, good for Pitru tarpan, water/food daan, and praying for relief from drought or suffering.
katha: Stories highlight feeding thirsty travellers and poor in Jyeshtha as special punya; pitru are said to be especially receptive.
morning: Pre‑dawn snan (river or Ganga jal); arrange tarpan items.
daytime: Perform tarpan/shraddha with priest or simple mantras; engage in annadaan and water distribution.
mainpuja: Evening simple deepa, brief Narayana/ancestor remembrance at home.
fasting-rules: Many keep partial fast or one‑meal satvik food; avoid non‑veg, onion/garlic, alcohol.
daan: Water, buttermilk, sharbat, food, clothes, umbrellas to poor and travellers.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” during tarpan; Gayatri japa for self.

english-name: Vat Savitri Vrat (North date may vary; BankBazaar notes 16 May)
tithi-month: Jyeshtha Amavasya or Jyeshtha Shukla Tritiya (regional) bankbazaar+1
significance: Married women fast and worship Vata (banyan) tree for long life of husband and family well‑being.
katha: Savitri’s husband Satyavan died under a tree; she followed Yama with steadfast devotion and cleverness, winning back Satyavan’s life and boons for her in‑laws.
morning: Morning snan; married women wear auspicious clothes, bangles, vermilion; collect puja items (thread, sweets).
daytime: Maintain fast (nirjal or fruits) while preparing for Vata puja; mentally recall Savitri’s devotion.
mainpuja: At banyan tree, circumambulate, tie sacred thread around trunk, offer water, kumkum, flowers; recite Savitri‑Satyavan katha; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja, usually with prasad and then satvik meal with husband/family.
daan: Food, clothes, bangles, cosmetics to married women and poor girls.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः सावित्र्यै” and simple “ॐ नमः शिवाय” (as tree often linked with Shiva).

english-name: Shani Jayanti (per some lists on Jyeshtha Amavasya or the next day)
tithi-month: Jyeshtha Amavasya or nearby date (check panchang) guptvrindavandham​
significance: Birthday of Shani Dev; fasting and worship believed to pacify Shani doshas, Sade‑Sati, and bring fair justice.
katha: Legends describe Shani as son of Surya and Chhaya, extremely strict but ultimately just; devotion on his Jayanti softens his influence.
morning: Morning bath; optionally wear dark/blue clothes; set Shani image or oil lamp at home.
daytime: Fasts on water/fruit; visit Shani temple (if available); read Shani Mahatmya or Shani katha.
mainpuja: Offer mustard oil, black sesame, black cloth/blanket at Shani altar or to poor; light sesame‑oil lamp; recite Shani stotra; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after main puja, ideally after donating oil/sesame; keep food non‑spicy and satvik.
daan: Black sesame, mustard oil, shoes, blankets to poor, workers, handicapped.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ शं शनैश्चराय नमः” 108/1008 times.

english-name: Shukla Pratipada – Ashadha Month (South calendars may differ)
significance: Month‑transition marker in some regional panchangs; start of new lunar month for specific states.
katha: Used in some traditions as time to review vows and adjust sadhana according to changing season.
morning: Morning snan; small home puja to family deities.
daytime: Plan monthly fasting pattern and japa goals.
mainpuja: Lamp lighting and aarti in evening.
fasting-rules: No obligatory fast; optional.
daan: Small charity (food/coins) to needy.
notes: Mainly structural/calendar note; include if you’re tracking all month transitions.

significance: Ganesha fast this time in Shukla Paksha, focusing on beginning new endeavours and resolving disputes.
katha: Similar general Chaturthi legends; emphasises that those who remember Ganesha at start of lunar bright half receive guidance and clarity.
morning: Morning bath; Ganesha sthapana; sankalpa for upvas.
daytime: Daylong japa of “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah;” avoid anger, confusion; plan projects on paper.
mainpuja: Evening full puja with abhishek, durva, modak; katha; aarti; Moon darshan + arghya.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after Moon‑Ganesha offerings; prasad first, then light meal.
daan: Modak, fruits; donations for education, removing “obstacles” of illiteracy.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times.

english-name: Nirjala Ekadashi (may fall in early June depending on tithi; if May in your chosen panchang, add here)
significance: One of the strictest Ekadashis – Nirjala (no water); said to give combined merit of all Ekadashis if done once with devotion.
katha: Bhima, unable to keep every Ekadashi, requested a single vrata; sage advised Nirjala Ekadashi, keeping him without food or water but granting full benefit.
morning: Very early snan; health‑wise evaluate capacity; sankalpa specifying Nirjala or phalahar variant.
daytime: Spend day in Vishnu japa, katha, satsang; avoid physical exertion and heat exposure if doing Nirjala.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja, aarti; rest and meditation.
fasting-rules: Parana next morning with water and tulsi first, then light food; if health issues, do only phalahar Ekadashi, not Nirjala.
daan: Water, sharbat, buttermilk distribution; food and clothes to poor.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ विष्णवे नमः” and “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108+ times.

muhurat: Snan‑daan from sunrise; best during Madhyahna panchang​
significance: Celebrates descent of Ganga from heaven to earth; river‑baths and charity destroy sins of ten lifetimes (“Dasha‑hara”).panchang​
katha: King Bhagiratha’s penance brought Ganga down to liberate his ancestors; Shiva held her in his matted locks to soften her fall, then released her on earth.
morning: Pre‑dawn or early river snan (or Ganga jal at home); wear clean clothes; resolve for snan‑daan.
daytime: Japa of “Ganga” nama, reading Ganga Mahatmya; distribute water, sharbat in the heat; maintain satvik food.
mainpuja: Evening aarti on riverbank or at home with Ganga jal; float diyas if possible; bhajans to Ganga and Shiva.
fasting-rules: Optional fast or one‑meal satvik diet; emphasis more on snan and charity than strict upvas.
daan: Water, sharbat, fruits, food, umbrellas, footwear to poor and travellers.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ श्री गंगे नमः” 108 times; “गंगे च यमुने चैव…” shloka.

tithi-month: Jyeshtha Shukla Dashami (same day as Ganga Dussehra) panchang​
significance: Appearance day of Maa Gayatri, embodiment of Vedas and Gayatri mantra; ideal for mantra‑diksha and japa.panchang+1
katha: Sage Vishwamitra is said to have brought Gayatri mantra to earth; she grants brilliance, intellect, and spiritual awakening to sincere chanters.
morning: Early snan; sit on asana facing east; mentally bow to Gayatri as radiant five‑faced Devi.
daytime: Perform Gayatri japa, anulom‑vilom, and simple meditation; study or listen to Gayatri Mahatmya; avoid harsh speech and tamasic food.
mainpuja: Evening small puja with lamp, flowers, and water; recite Gayatri aarti and some more japa.
fasting-rules: No strict fast required; some keep fruits‑only to facilitate sadhana; avoid overeating and non‑veg.
daan: Books, pens, food to students; donations to Gurukuls, ashrams.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ भूः भुवः स्वः तत्सवितुर्वरेण्यं…” 108/1008 times (Gayatri).

tithi-month: Jyeshtha Shukla Amavasya or Tritiya depending system panchang​
significance: Married women fast and worship banyan (Vat) for long life of husband, marital happiness, and family well‑being.panchang​
katha: Princess Savitri chose Satyavan as husband knowing he’d die in a year; when Yama took his soul, she followed, skillfully gained boons, and finally restored Satyavan’s life.
morning: Morning snan; married women wear auspicious clothes, sindoor, bangles; prepare puja thali (thread, sweets, akshata).
daytime: Fast (often nirjal or fruits) while preparing Vata puja; keep mind on Savitri’s devotion and courage.
mainpuja: At Vat tree, circumambulate, tie sacred thread, offer water, kumkum, flowers; recite Savitri‑Satyavan vrat katha; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast generally broken after puja with prasad then satvik meal; some wait till evening.
daan: Food, clothes, bangles, sindoor, cosmetics to married women and poor girls.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः सावित्र्यै” + “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108 times.

significance: Ekadashi praised for removing sins, diseases, and especially results of misdeeds against others.panchang+1
katha: Katha: a gardener who neglected feeding his guru and stole fruits suffered leprosy; after keeping Yogini Ekadashi fast, he was cured and reached Vishnu’s abode.
morning: Early bath; install Vishnu image; sankalpa for full Ekadashi vrat.
daytime: No grains; fruits, milk, or water‑fast depending on strength; recite Vishnu Sahasranama and Yogini Ekadashi katha.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu or Satyanarayan puja; tulsi‑archana, aarti, bhajan; meditate on forgiveness and making amends.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi after sunrise and puja; break with water‑tulsi then light satvik food.
daan: Food, grains, sesame, blankets; service to sick or elderly.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108/1008 times.

significance: Twilight fast for removal of sins, better health, and success; generic Krishna Pradosh.panchang​
katha: As with other Pradosh stories, Shiva’s Tandava at this time answered devas’ prayers; fasting and puja then attracts similar grace.
morning: Morning snan; clean altar; set Shivalinga; vow for Pradosh upvas.
daytime: Fast with fruits/milk; chant “Om Namah Shivaya,” read Shiv Chalisa; avoid negative influences.
mainpuja: In Pradosh Kaal, perform abhishek, bilva‑archana, incense, lamp; Mahamrityunjaya japa; aarti.
fasting-rules: Break fast after puja with light satvik food.
daan: Milk, rice, white sweets; bel‑leaves and oil lamps to Shiva temples.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108+; Mahamrityunjaya 108 if possible.

significance: Sun’s transit into Gemini, supportive for communication, study, and networking; auspicious day for Surya upasana and daan.
katha: Each Sankranti has specific effects; Mithuna’s airy nature favors learning, travel, and balanced thinking when aligned with dharma.
morning: Morning snan; offer arghya to Sun with Surya mantra.
daytime: Reflect on communication habits; plan learning/teaching seva; small charity.
mainpuja: Evening diya and brief Surya aarti at home.
fasting-rules: No formal fast; optional light, sattvic diet.
daan: Food, books, pens, spectacles for students/elderly.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ घृणि सू्र्याय नमः” 108 times.

significance: Some calendars put Gayatri Jayanti here; follow either 8 or 23 June and note alternative in Excel.drikpanchang+1
katha: Same Gayatri appearance story and significance as above.
morning: As on 8 June: snan, dhyana, Gayatri invocation.
daytime: Gayatri japa, scriptural study, quiet reflective work.
mainpuja: Small evening puja and aarti.
fasting-rules: No special fast; focus on sadhana.
daan: Books, food to students; support to spiritual orgs.
notes: Mantra‑japa: Gayatri mantra 108/1008 times. Note alt date in “Notes.”

significance: Considered most powerful Ekadashi; Nirjala (no water) observance equals all 24 Ekadashis together if done sincerely.exoticindiaart+1
katha: Bhima couldn’t fast every Ekadashi; sage advised Nirjala Ekadashi alone; despite difficulty he kept it and gained full benefit, establishing this vrata’s special status.
morning: Very early snan; assess health honestly; sankalpa specifying Nirjala (no water) or normal phalahar Ekadashi if not possible.
daytime: Spend day remembering Vishnu, reading Bhagavad Gita or Sahasranama; avoid sun/heat exposure if Nirjala; speak minimally and truthfully.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu/Satyanarayan puja, tulsi‑archana, aarti; quiet meditation.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi next morning with water and tulsi first, then light food; if weak, do standard Ekadashi instead of Nirjala.
daan: Water, sharbat, buttermilk, food, clothes to poor and sadhus.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ विष्णवे नमः” and “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय,” 108+ each.

tithi-month: Jyeshtha Shukla Dwadashi (overlaps Nirjala Parana) drikpanchang+1
significance: Dwadashi dedicated to Rama–Lakshmana; observed for protection, family unity, victory over enemies.drikpanchang​
katha: Some traditions say Rama and Lakshmana rested after long exile on this tithi; worship grants strength and brotherhood.
morning: Morning snan; place Ram‑Lakshman‑Sita image; if just finished Nirjala, prepare for Parana.
daytime: Short Ramayana reading or RAM‑nama japa; offer simple satvik naivedya.
mainpuja: Aarti to Rama–Lakshmana; family prayer for unity and strength.
fasting-rules: Ekadashi Parana coincides; break fast with prasad and then light meal.
daan: Food, clothes, support for siblings/orphans.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम” 108 times.

tithi-month: Jyeshtha Shukla Trayodashi (evening of same fortnight) drikpanchang​
significance: Friday Pradosh emphasises wealth, comfort, marital happiness, and clearing financial troubles.
katha: Devas are said to have performed Pradosh on Friday to regain lost prosperity; Shiva, with Lakshmi’s subtle grace, blessed them.
morning: Morning snan; wear clean, preferably white/light clothes; sankalpa for Pradosh fast.
daytime: Phalahar fast; recite “Om Namah Shivaya,” Lakshmi ashtakam or Kanakadhara (optional).
mainpuja: In Pradosh Kaal, full Shiva abhishek; offer white flowers, sweets; Mahamrityunjaya japa; aarti; meditate on inner contentment rather than greed.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja with light satvik food.
daan: Milk, sweets, rice, clothes to poor couples, girls.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” + “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” 108 each.

muhurat: Parana after sunrise, within Dwadashi drikpanchang​
significance: Proper completion of Nirjala Ekadashi ensuring full merit and no dosha from delayed Parana.
katha: As per traditions, Parana during Dwadashi is integral; late breaking reduces ekadashi punya.
morning: Morning snan, brief Vishnu puja.
daytime: Prepare very light satvik food for Parana.
mainpuja: Simple evening aarti as gratitude.
fasting-rules: Break fast as per exact panchang timing; water+Tulsi first, then simple food.
daan: Food, water, sharbat to poor.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 11–27 times as thanksgiving.

english-name: Yogini Ekadashi (alt. date – some sources put here, DrikPanchang/temple lists may differ)
tithi-month: Ashadha Krishna Ekadashi (if falls in late June for some panchangs) radhakrishnatemple​
significance: Same as 10 June row: for removing disease and result of past misdeeds; note which date your chosen panchang gives and keep one as “alt date”.
katha: Same Medhavi–Manjughosha katha and meaning.
morning: Same procedure as Yogini row above.
daytime: Same.
mainpuja: Same.
fasting-rules: Same.
daan: Same.
notes: Mantra‑japa: same as above; note alternative date in “Notes.”

english-name: Ashadha Amavasya (per Panchang.org: June 25; some list 26)
significance: New moon at start of rainy season; important for Pitru tarpan, removing Pitru dosha, and seeking protection from disease.
katha: Texts say Ashadha/Pitru works here help families face monsoon‑related difficulties with divine support.
morning: Early snan (river or Ganga jal); arrange tarpan implements.
daytime: Perform tarpan; give charity especially of umbrellas, rain‑gear, food; maintain sattvic conduct.
mainpuja: Evening deepa and Narayana puja.
fasting-rules: Many observe partial fast or single‑meal satvik food; avoid non‑veg and intoxicants.
daan: Rain‑gear, food, umbrellas, clothes to poor; sesame and food to Brahmins.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” and “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 times; note whether your base panchang uses 25 or 26 June.

muhurat: Snan‑daan morning; Guru puja mid‑morning; satsang evening panchang+1
significance: Day to worship Guru‑tattva and Maharishi Ved Vyasa, compiler of Vedas and Puranas; ideal for diksha, seva, and gratitude.panchang+1
katha: Legend: Vyasa divided Vedas, wrote Mahabharata and Puranas; deities praised him as Jagad‑Guru. Traditionally all gurus are worshipped this day as Vyasa’s manifestations.
morning: Early snan; clean altar; place photos of personal Guru, Ved Vyasa, or generic Guru image.
daytime: Maintain partial fast or light sattvik food; read Guru Gita / teachings of your Guru; introspect on past year’s sadhana.
mainpuja: Perform Guru puja: paduka/ photo abhishek (water, milk), sandal paste, flowers; offer dakshina; do aarti and kirtan/satsang.
fasting-rules: If fasting, break after Guru puja and dakshina; keep diet simple.
daan: Dakshina to Guru, books, clothes, food to Brahmins and poor students.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ गुरवे नमः” and “ॐ व्यासाय नमः” 108 times each.

significance: Monthly Sankashti with specific name “Krishnapingala”; removes deep‑rooted problems and gives courage, stability.bhaktipulse​
katha: Each Sankashti has a form/name of Ganesha and dedicated katha; Krishnapingala is said to free from prolonged debts, fears, and chronic issues.
morning: Pre‑dawn bath; place Ganesha murti; sankalpa to fast till Moonrise.
daytime: Observe nirjal or fruit fast; japa of “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah;” read specific Krishnapingala Sankashti katha if available.
mainpuja: Evening puja with abhishek, durva, red flowers, modak; listen to/read the vrat katha; aarti; Moon darshan and arghya.
fasting-rules: Fast broken only after seeing Moon and offering arghya and naivedya to Moon and Ganesha.
daan: Modak, laddoo, fruits; books/fees for children.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times.

significance: Kalashtami: worship of Bhairava for protection; Masik Janmashtami: monthly remembrance of Krishna’s birth for bhakti and wish‑fulfilment.bhaktipulse​
katha: Kalashtami katha: Shiva manifested as Bhairava to destroy ego and protect dharma. Masik Janmashtami keeps Krishna’s appearance alive in devotee’s heart each month.
morning: Morning snan; set Bhairava and Krishna images; take sankalpa for upvas if able.
daytime: For Kalashtami, chant Bhairava stotra; for Janmashtami, read Bhagavatam/ Gita; light diet or fast.
mainpuja: Night: simple Krishna janma puja around midnight – abhishek, dress, offer butter, sweets; sing kirtan; for Bhairava, evening deepa and stotra.
fasting-rules: Those fasting may stay on water/fruits till midnight puja, then break after offering to Krishna.
daan: Food, dogs’ feeding (for Bhairava), sweets for children.
notes: Mantra‑japa: Krishna – “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय;” Bhairava – “ॐ कालभैरवाय नमः” (108 each).

significance: Very important Ekadashi for removing diseases, poverty, and sins, especially those due to neglecting duties to others.panchang​
katha: Katha of gardener Hemamali who ignored his wife and master, stole flowers; cursed with disease and misery; by Yogini Ekadashi he was purified and reached Vishnu’s loka.
morning: Morning bath; install Vishnu image; sankalpa for Ekadashi vrat.
daytime: No grains; fruit/milk or water fast; Vishnu Sahasranama, Yogini Ekadashi katha; cultivate forgiveness and charity.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu/Satyanarayan puja; tulsi‑archana, aarti, bhajans.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi with water‑tulsi and light satvik food after Vishnu puja.
daan: Food, grains, clothes, medicines donation if possible.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108/1008 times.

significance: In Vaishnava system date may shift by a day; Dwadashi here honored as Rama‑Lakshmana day for protection and family unity.bhaktipulse​
katha: Same Yogini story; Ramalakshmana Dwadashi recalls their brotherly bond and protective energy during exile.
morning: If following Vaishnava panchang, keep Ekadashi fast this day as above.
daytime: Similar Ekadashi rules; more focus on nama‑japa and seva at Vaishnava temples.
mainpuja: Dwadashi morning: simple puja to Rama‑Lakshmana with aarti and katha listening.
fasting-rules: Parana in Dwadashi, combining gratitude to Vishnu and Rama‑Lakshmana.
daan: Food, clothes, help to siblings/children.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम” 108 times alongside Vishnu nama.

tithi-month: When Rohini Nakshatra rises (Ashadha Krishna Trayodashi–Chaturdashi) bhaktipulse​
significance: Popular mainly among Jains and some Vaishnavas for prosperity, freedom from poverty and family troubles.bhaktipulse​
katha: Jaina legend: King’s queen freed from miseries by observing Rohini fasts as instructed by Tirthankara; Vaishnava angle: Rohini Nakshatra linked to Krishna (his birth star).
morning: Morning snan; vow to fast during Rohini period; worship Krishna or preferred deity.
daytime: Fast on water/fruits; do nama‑japa and simple charity.
mainpuja: Evening short puja and aarti; listen to Rohini Vrat katha if following Jain tradition.
fasting-rules: Parana at end of Rohini Nakshatra or next morning depending on vrata‑vidhi.
daan: Food, grains, help to poor women/families.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” or Jain “णमो अरिहंताणं” as per tradition.

muhurat: Pradosh Kaal (~7:05–9:30 PM) & night Nishita bhaktipulse​
significance: Rare combo: Sunday Pradosh + Masik Shivaratri, excellent for health, removal of ego, and deep Shiva‑bhakti.
katha: Pradosh legends plus Shivaratri jyotirlinga story; combined, this night is very strong for turning within and healing.
morning: Morning snan; vow for fast; Shivalinga sthapana.
daytime: Phalahar or nirjal; japa of “Om Namah Shivaya;” read some Shiva‑katha.
mainpuja: Pradosh: full abhishek and aarti; continue into night with 4‑prahar Shivaratri puja, more abhishek, bilva, mantra‑japa, meditation.
fasting-rules: Fast usually kept from sunrise till next morning after dawn puja and Surya arghya.
daan: Milk, bel leaves, water, food to sadhus/poor.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” many malas; Mahamrityunjaya 108 times.

muhurat: Snan‑daan morning; pitru rites forenoon bhaktipulse​
significance: New moon of Ashadha, important for Pitru tarpan, charity, and preparing for Shravan month.
katha: Puranas extol Amavasya shraddha as giving peace to ancestors; Ashadha’s rains make daan of food/clothing especially valuable.
morning: Early snan (river if possible); set tarpan tray with water, black sesame, darbha.
daytime: Perform tarpan/shraddha with priest or standard mantras; maintain quiet, sattvik behaviour.
mainpuja: Evening diya, Narayana/ family‑deity aarti.
fasting-rules: Optional fast or single satvik meal; avoid non‑veg, alcohol, and arguments.
daan: Food, sesame, clothes, umbrellas/rain‑gear to poor.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” and “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 times.

muhurat: Morning Ghatasthapana; Chandra Darshan just after sunset bhaktipulse​
significance: Start of Gupt (Ashadha) Navratri for more internal, tantric‑style Devi sadhana; first Moon sighting after Amavasya for mind‑peace.
katha: Hidden Navratri is said to be preferred by sadhaks for inner work; Chandra Darshan balances manas‑tattva.
morning: Morning snan; Ghatasthapana for Navratri (kalash, Durga photo, akshat); sankalpa for 9‑day vrat.
daytime: Partial fast (one meal or fruits), Durga Saptashati reading, “Ya Devi Sarvabhuteshu” japa.
mainpuja: After sunset, sight Moon, offer arghya with rice/water; small Devi aarti.
fasting-rules: Navratri fast continues till Ashtami/Navami; Chandra Darshan does not require separate fast.
daan: Food, clothes, fruits to girls/women; rice, sweets at Moon‑darshan.
notes: Mantra‑japa: Durga – “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः;” Chandra – “ॐ चन्द्राय नमः” (11–27 times).

tithi-month: Ashadha Shukla Dwitiya; Sun enters Cancer
significance: Rathyatra: chariot festival of Jagannath symbolising God coming out to give darshan. Karka Sankranti marks Sun entering Cancer and start of Dakshinayana.
katha: Story: Jagannath, Balabhadra, Subhadra annually travel from main temple to Gundicha, giving darshan to all, including those who cannot enter temple. Dakshinayana is half‑year of Sun’s southern journey.
morning: Morning snan; keep Jagannath image or focus on Krishna; offer simple bhog.
daytime: Visit local Jagannath/ISKCON temple if possible; pull chariot rope if allowed; keep sattvik food.
mainpuja: Evening kirtan, bhajan; aarti to Jagannath; small Surya aarti for Sankranti.
fasting-rules: No fast required; some keep light diet as respect.
daan: Food, fruits, water to pilgrims; donations to Jagannath temples.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “जय जगन्नाथ” and Maha‑mantra – “हरे कृष्ण हरे कृष्ण कृष्ण कृष्ण हरे हरे…”

significance: Chaturthi dedicated to Aniruddha (Vishnu aspect), observed for protection from sudden troubles and to strengthen resolve.
katha: Aniruddha is one of four vyuha forms of Vishnu; some regional Kathas link this Chaturthi to stories of demons defeated by divine intervention.
morning: Morning snan; install Vishnu/Ganesha image; sankalpa for simple vrat.
daytime: Light fast; recite Vishnu Sahasranama or relevant katha; maintain peaceful conduct.
mainpuja: Evening puja with fruits, flowers; aarti to Aniruddha/Vishnu & Ganesha.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja with satvik meal.
daan: Food, grains, books for students, help to those in sudden distress.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ अनिरुद्धाय नमः” or “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 times.

significance: Monthly Skanda Shashti for victory, courage, clarity, and conquering inner enemies.
katha: Remembers Skanda’s victory over demon Surapadma using Vel; seen as general symbol of spiritual conquest.
morning: Morning snan; place Kartikeya image or Vel symbol; vow for fast if able.
daytime: Light fruits‑only fast; recite Skanda shashti kavacham or simple Murugan stotras.
mainpuja: Evening aarti with red flowers, fruits; offer coconut, bananas.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after evening puja with satvik food.
daan: Fruits, sweets, gifts to boys and students.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ सरवनभवाय नमः” 108 times.

significance: Birth day of Parvati, plus monthly Durga Ashtami; good for marriage, fertility, strength, and protection.bhaktipulse​
katha: Puranas describe Parvati’s tapas to win Shiva; monthly Durgashtami recalls Devi’s vow to protect devotees who remember her.
morning: Morning snan; place Parvati/Durga image; wear red/yellow; sankalpa for Ashtami vrat.
daytime: Upvas (fruits/milk) or one‑meal fast; chant “Ya Devi Sarvabhuteshu;” read small Devi katha.
mainpuja: Evening Durga puja: kumkum, flowers, incense, naivedya; aarti; optional Kanya pujan if you wish.
fasting-rules: Fast usually ends after evening puja with prasad and satvik meal.
daan: Food, clothes, bangles, kumkum to girls/women.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ पार्वत्यै नमः” or “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108 times.

significance: Regional vrat (esp. North & East) for family welfare and protection during monsoon.bhaktipulse​
katha: Stories vary; commonly a household freed from calamities by observing this Navami vrat with charity and cleanliness.
morning: Morning snan; simple home puja to Durga/Vishnu.
daytime: Light fast or simple satvik meal; charity to poor; refrain from harshness/anger.
mainpuja: Short evening aarti and bhajan.
fasting-rules: Fast broken with simple food after puja.
daan: Food, grains, clothes to needy families.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” or “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108 times.

hindi-name: आशा दशमी व्रत, रैवतः मन्वन्तर प्रारंभ
significance: Dashami vrata for hope (asha), wish‑fulfilment, and removal of despair; Raivata Manvadi is a scriptural marker of a cosmic Manvantara.
katha: Puranic context: different Manus rule cosmic ages; Raivata is one such Manu; Dashami vrat legends emphasise devotees regaining hope after misfortunes.
morning: Morning snan; simple puja to Vishnu.
daytime: Light fast or one‑meal; japa and reading of small Purana stories.
mainpuja: Short evening aarti.
fasting-rules: No strict rules; optional fast ends at sunset.
daan: Food, grains, help to those in depression/difficulty.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 times.

english-name: Devshayani Ekadashi & Vasudeva Dwadashi, Gauri Vrat Begins
hindi-name: देवशयनी एकादशी, वासुदेव द्वादशी, गौरी व्रत
significance: Devshayani: Vishnu goes into Yoga‑nidra on Kshirasagara; start of Chaturmas; Dwadashi for Vasudeva; Gauri Vrat for girls and women.
katha: Katha: on this day Vishnu sleeps for four months (Chaturmas) and wakes on Prabodhini Ekadashi; devotees focus more on bhajan and less on travel/marriages.
morning: Morning snan; sankalpa for Devshayani Ekadashi fast; set Vishnu image.
daytime: Ekadashi rules: no grains; chant Vishnu Sahasranama, hear Devshayani katha; women/girls start Gauri Vrat for marriage/prosperity.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja, aarti, bhajan; for Gauri, simple Devi puja.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi; many continue Gauri Vrat multiple days; food satvik.
daan: Food, grains, clothes, support to temples/ashrams.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108/1008 times; Gauri – “ॐ गौरी नमः” 108 times.

significance: Sunday Pradosh for health, radiance, and relief from Surya‑related doshas.
katha: Same Pradosh legends; on Ravi (Sunday) focus is on vitality and ego‑purification.
morning: Morning snan; Pradosh vrat sankalpa; Shivaling ready.
daytime: Fast with fruits/milk; Shiva nama‑japa; avoid anger and arrogance.
mainpuja: In Pradosh, abhishek, bilva, incense; Mahamrityunjaya chanting; aarti.
fasting-rules: Break fast after puja with light food.
daan: Ghee, wheat, jaggery, white clothes to poor.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108+; Mahamrityunjaya 108.

tithi-month: Ashadha Shukla Trayodashi (5‑day vrat into Purnima) bhaktipulse​
significance: Popular in Gujarat; five‑day vrat by women/girls for marital harmony and good husband.
katha: Legend: a girl’s devotion to Parvati, through this 5‑day vrat, resulted in marriage to desired groom and overall family prosperity.
morning: First‑day snan; vow for 5‑day Jayaparvati vrat; Parvati image set.
daytime: Through 5 days, eat one‑time simple satvik food (often no wheat/rice, only fruits/millet etc.), daily Parvati puja.
mainpuja: Each evening, small Gauri/Parvati puja with lamp, flowers, aarti.
fasting-rules: Vrat ends on Purnima with special puja and feast (see 28 July).
daan: Food, clothes, bangles to girls/women.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ जयापार्वत्यै नमः” or “ॐ पार्वत्यै नमः” daily 108 times.

significance: Kokila Vrat: for marital happiness and removal of loneliness, associated with cuckoo (kokila); Chaumasi Chaudas: marks four‑month tapas period.bhaktipulse​
katha: Story: woman cursed as kokila bird regained human form and happiness by observing this vrat. Chaumasi Chaudas: ascetics and householders begin stricter discipline for four months.
morning: Morning snan; worship Radha‑Krishna or chosen deity; vow for vrat.
daytime: Simple fast/one meal; japa; avoid harsh speech (like crow), cultivate sweet speech (like kokila).
mainpuja: Evening bhajan, aarti; end of Jayaparvati Vrat with special Parvati puja and feast.
fasting-rules: Vrats generally broken after evening puja with satvik feast.
daan: Food, sweets, clothes; annadaan.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “राधे कृष्ण” nama japa; Jayaparvati devotees also chant Parvati mantra.

muhurat: Snan‑daan morning; Guru puja mid‑morning panchang+1
significance: In some regional reckoning, Guru Purnima marked this day; already noted 1 July from another source—choose one as primary and keep other as alt.
katha: Same Vyasa/Guru lore as 1 July row.
morning: Same morning pattern: snan, Guru/ Vyasa puja.
daytime: Study teachings, satsang, seva.
mainpuja: Evening aarti, kirtan.
fasting-rules: Light fast broken after Guru puja.
daan: Same dakshina and charity practices.
notes: Mantra‑japa: same Guru/Vyasa mantras; note in “Notes” which date your site adopts.

significance: Beginning of Shravan month, extremely auspicious for Shiva worship, Kanwar‑yatra, and enhanced sadhana.
katha: Texts call Shravan dear to Shiva; each Monday especially powerful; also used for Vishnu upasana in some Vaishnava sampradayas.
morning: Morning snan; resolve extra japa/puja for entire Shravan (e.g., Shravan Somvar fasts).
daytime: Plan Monday fasts, rudrabhishek days, and charity; keep mind oriented to tapas.
mainpuja: Evening diya, Shiva aarti; possibly start first rudrabhishek.
fasting-rules: No specific fast first day (unless Monday); focus is on month‑long discipline.
daan: Water, milk, bel leaves to Shiva temples; food to poor/kanwariyas.
notes: Mantra‑japa: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108+ daily throughout Shravan.

significance: Completion of 5‑day Jayaparvati vrat, mainly in Gujarat, for marital happiness and good husband.
katha: Girl/woman whose devotion pleased Parvati observed 5‑day fast and gained desired husband/prosperity.
morning: Snan; Parvati puja with flowers and kumkum.
daytime: Prepare special satvik food; invite family/girls.
mainpuja: Final aarti to Parvati; distribute prasad and feast.
fasting-rules: Vrat broken this morning with prasad then full satvik bhojan.
daan: Food, clothes, bangles to girls/women.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ पार्वत्यै नमः” 108 times.

significance: Sankashti for removal of obstacles, debt, court cases, exam fear, especially under water‑heavy Shravan.
katha: Gajanana Sankashti katha describes a devotee freed from poverty and disgrace after this specific Chaturthi fast and katha‑shravan.
morning: Pre‑dawn bath; install Ganesha; sankalpa for fast till Moonrise.
daytime: Nirjal/fruit fast; japa of “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah;” read Atharvashirsha.
mainpuja: Evening puja, abhishek, durva, red flowers, modak; Gajanana Sankashti katha; aarti; Moon darshan and arghya.
fasting-rules: Fast broken only after Moon & Ganesha offerings; begin with prasad then light meal.
daan: Modak, laddoo, fruits; books for students.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108–1008 times.

english-name: First Shravan Somvar Vrat; Aadi Perukku (TN)
hindi-name: प्रथम श्रावण सोमवार व्रत; आदि पेरुक्कु
significance: Start of Shravan Somvar series; ideal for Shiva bhakti, marriage and health; Aadi Perukku honours rivers’ abundance.
katha: Somvar katha: woman gained ideal husband and prosperity by Shravan Monday fasts; Aadi Perukku linked to Kaveri blessing lands with fertility.
morning: Morning snan; white clothes; set Shivalinga; sankalpa for Monday fast.
daytime: Upvas on milk/fruits/one meal; japa “Om Namah Shivaya;” for Aadi Perukku, simple river puja if following Tamil tradition.
mainpuja: Evening Shiva abhishek, bilva‑puja, aarti; family bhajans.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after evening puja with satvik food (no onion/garlic).
daan: Milk, bel leaves, water, food to poor; offerings at riverbanks.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” many malas through the day.

tithi-month: Shravana Krishna Panchami; 1st Tuesday in Shravan
significance: Married and newly‑married women worship Gauri for marital bliss and prosperity on Shravan Tuesdays.
katha: Katha: a poverty‑stricken girl’s fortune changed after regular Mangala Gauri vrat; she got good husband and wealth by Devi’s grace.
morning: Morning snan; women wear auspicious clothes; simple Gauri photo/idol set.
daytime: Daytime prep of puja items (turmeric, kumkum, bangles, sweets); maintain satvik thoughts.
mainpuja: Evening Mangala Gauri puja, offering 16 shringar items, fruits, sweets; games and bhajans with women; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast (often one‑meal/fruit) broken after puja with prasad and dinner.
daan: Bangles, kumkum, clothes to married women and girls.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ गौरी नमः” or “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108 times.

muhurat: Daytime Bhairava; midnight Krishna upasana bhaktipulse​
significance: Kalashtami for Bhairava protection; monthly Janmashtami for deepening Krishna bhakti.
katha: Bhairava manifested to curb ego; monthly Janmashtami remembers Krishna’s avataric birth as ongoing inner event.
morning: Snan; set Bhairava and Krishna images; sankalpa for fast if possible.
daytime: Upvas on fruits/milk; Bhairava stotra and Gita/Bhagavatam reading.
mainpuja: Night: small Krishna‑birth puja, abhishek, butter, sweets, aarti around midnight; Bhairava lamp and stotra in evening.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after midnight Krishna puja or next morning depending on strength.
daan: Food to dogs (Bhairava), sweets/opah to children.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ कालभैरवाय नमः” and “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108 each.

significance: Monthly lamp festival, especially Tamil tradition; deepa‑lighting removes darkness of ignorance.
katha: Linked to Shiva as column of light and Murugan’s birth from sparks from Shiva’s third eye.
morning: Evening snan; clean puja area.
daytime: Prepare many oil lamps; keep mind on inner light.
mainpuja: Light rows of deepa at dusk; Shiva/Murugan aarti; bhajans.
fasting-rules: No set fast; optional light diet.
daan: Oil, wicks, lamps to temples; food to poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” or “ॐ सरवनभवाय नमः” 108 times.

significance: For prosperity, relief from suffering and poverty, especially among Jain and some Vaishnava families.
katha: Jain queen released from miseries by Rohini fasts; Vaishnavas connect Rohini to Krishna’s star and favour.
morning: Morning snan; choose deity (Krishna or Tirthankara image).
daytime: Fruit/water fast; nama‑japa, listening to Rohini vrat katha.
mainpuja: Simple evening puja and aarti; charity.
fasting-rules: Parana at Rohini end or next day morning (per family tradition).
daan: Food, grains, donations to poor families.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” or “णमो अरिहंताणं” (Jain) 108 times.

significance: Kamika Ekadashi destroys grave sins, especially violence or harsh speech, and gives Vishnu‑lok; Dwadashi honours Krishna Vasudeva.
katha: Katha: a sinful man gained liberation by Kamika Ekadashi fast and Tulsi‑offering to Vishnu; even hearing its glories gives great punya.
morning: Early snan; install Vishnu/Krishna image; Ekadashi sankalpa.
daytime: No grains; fruits/milk or stricter fast; Vishnu Sahasranama, Kamika Ekadashi katha; avoid anger.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja; tulsi‑archana, aarti, bhajan.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi with tulsi‑water and satvik food after puja.
daan: Food, grains, sesame, help to poor and priests.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108/1008 times.

english-name: Second Shravan Somvar; Soma Pradosh Vrat
hindi-name: दूसरा श्रावण सोमवार; सोम प्रदोष व्रत
significance: Monday Pradosh inside Shravan; very strong for health, marriage, and dissolving past karmas.
katha: Devas saved at Pradosh by Shiva’s grace; Shravan Somvar stories of barren couples and troubled families finding relief through these fasts.
morning: Morning snan; Shravan Somvar + Pradosh sankalpa; Shivalinga sthapana.
daytime: Upvas on milk/fruits/one meal; Shiva nama‑japa; avoid tamasic inputs.
mainpuja: Pradosh Kaal: full abhishek, bilva, dhoop‑deep, Mahamrityunjaya; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after Pradosh puja with light satvik food.
daan: Milk, curd, rice, bel leaves; food to poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” and “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108 times.

english-name: Sawan Shivaratri; Second Mangala Gauri; Masik Shivaratri
hindi-name: सावन शिवरात्रि; दूसरा मंगला गौरी; मासिक शिवरात्रि
muhurat: Night Nishita; evening Devi puja bhaktipulse+1
significance: Peak Shravan Shivratri, plus Mangala Gauri; ideal for intense Shiva sadhana and Gauri upasana.
katha: Combines Jyotirlinga‑night story with Parvati’s tapas for Shiva; very potent night for breaking addictions and negative patterns.
morning: Morning snan; decide Nirjal/fruit fast; Shivalinga and Gauri images set.
daytime: Upvas; Shiva nama‑japa, Durga/Gauri stotra; women keep Mangala Gauri vrat with preparations.
mainpuja: Night: 4‑prahar Shiva puja (abhishek, bilva, mantra, aarti); evening Mangala Gauri puja with shringar and bhajans.
fasting-rules: Fast kept to next morning after dawn Shiva puja and Surya arghya; Mangala Gauri fast broken after evening puja.
daan: Food, water, milk, bel; bangles, clothes for women.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” many malas; “ॐ गौरी नमः” 108 times.

english-name: Hariyali Amavasya; Aadi Amavasai; Surya Grahan (Purna)
hindi-name: हरियाली अमावस्या; आदि अमावासै; सूर्य ग्रहण
muhurat: Snan‑daan morning; grahan rules as per timings bhaktipulse+1
significance: Hariyali Amavasya celebrates greenery, monsoon fertility; Aadi Amavasai for Tamil Pitru rites; Surya Grahan adds eclipsed‑Sun snan‑daan and mantra‑japa.
katha: Puranas say Amavasya snan and tree‑planting in Shravan gives long‑lasting punya; eclipses seen as times when japa is especially fruitful.
morning: Pre‑grahan snan; if grahan visible, avoid cooking/eating during eclipse; do japa.
daytime: Plant trees, worship Tulsi/Peepal; Pitru tarpan (Aadi Amavasai) especially in South tradition.
mainpuja: After grahan moksha, snan again, daan of food, clothes; simple home aarti.
fasting-rules: Many keep upvas or one‑meal fast, breaking after grahan and snan.
daan: Food, saplings, clothes, sesame, water to poor.
notes: Mantra: Gayatri or “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108+ during grahan; “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” for tarpan.

muhurat: Just after sunset, crescent sighting bhaktipulse​
significance: First waxing Moon sight brings calm mind, emotional balance, and new‑cycle intention.
katha: Linked to Chandra’s curse and refuge in Shiva’s locks; honouring Moon balances manas‑tattva.
morning: Normal snan; prepare rice, milk sweet, water plate.
daytime: Maintain peaceful thoughts; plan to view Moon early night.
mainpuja: At first sight, offer arghya with water/rice; chant Chandra mantra; small aarti.
fasting-rules: No fast; some eat after Chandra Darshan.
daan: Rice, white sweets, milk to children/poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ चन्द्राय नमः” 11–27 times.

muhurat: Daytime swings & puja; evening songs bankbazaar+1
significance: Women’s festival of marital happiness and prosperity; also India’s Independence Day (not ritual).
katha: Teej katha tells of Parvati’s many births/tapas before Shiva accepted her; symbolises steadfast love and devotion.
morning: Snan; married women wear green/bandhani clothes, mehendi; decorate swings.
daytime: Upvas (often nirjal) for husband’s long life; singing Teej songs, visiting parents’ home.
mainpuja: Evening Gauri‑Shankar puja with sweets, fruits, bangles; aarti; then light meal.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja, generally at night, with satvik food.
daan: Bangles, mehendi, clothes to girls/women; food to poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ गौरी शंकराय नमः” 108 times.

significance: Special Chaturthi where Durva grass offering is emphasised, for success, progeny, and removal of obstacles.
katha: Katha says Durva cooled Ganesha when he swallowed fire or anger; hence he loves durva, granting boons to those who offer it.
morning: Pre‑dawn snan; Ganesha sthapana; sankalpa for Chaturthi fast.
daytime: Fruit/water fast; collect fresh durva in 21 or 108‑blade bundles; japa of Ganesh mantra.
mainpuja: Evening: abhishek, offer multiple durva bundles, modak; vrat katha; aarti; Moon darshan and arghya.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after Moon & Ganesha offerings; prasad then food.
daan: Modak, laddoo, stationery for students.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times.

english-name: Nag Panchami; 3rd Shravan Somvar; Simha Sankranti; Malayalam New Year (Chingam 1); Skanda Sashti
hindi-name: नाग पंचमी; तीसरा श्रावण सोमवार; सिंह संक्रांति; चिंगम १; स्कंद षष्ठी
tithi-month: Shravana Shukla Panchami–Shashthi; Sun enters Leo
muhurat: Morning–forenoon snake puja; all‑day Shiva/Sun; Skanda morning bhaktipulse+1
focus: Nag Devatas; Shiva; Surya; Skanda; regional deities
significance: Nag Panchami for serpent worship (kundalini, protection); Shravan Somvar again; Sun into Leo; Malayali New Year; Skanda Sashti for victory.
katha: Legends: Krishna subdued Kaliya Naag; also story of farmer’s family saved by snake’s blessing; Skanda’s victory over Surapadma; Chingam 1 as auspicious new start.
morning: Morning snan; draw or place Naga images; avoid digging earth that day; do Shravan Somvar sankalpa as well.
daytime: Milk and turmeric to anthills or snake shrines; light fast or no frying; japa of Shiva and Naga mantras; Malayali families mark Chingam with special puja.
mainpuja: Evening Shiva aarti; simple Skanda puja with red flowers, coconut; Surya aarti for Simha Sankranti.
fasting-rules: If fasting, break post‑puja with satvik food; Shravan Somvar fast can be as per your chosen pattern.
daan: Milk, food, grains; donations for snake temples, Annadanam.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय,” Nag – “ॐ नमो नागदेव्यै,” Skanda – “ॐ सरवनभवाय नमः” (108 each as per focus).

hindi-name: कल्कि जयंती; तीसरा मंगला गौरी व्रत
significance: Kalki Jayanti remembers future avatar who will end Kali Yuga; Mangala Gauri again for married women.
katha: Puranas describe Kalki as horse‑riding warrior who restores dharma at end of age; today’s remembrance inspires living dharmically.
morning: Morning snan; Vishnu/Kalki image; for women, Gauri image.
daytime: Light fast; reading Kalki Purana excerpts and Devi stotra; maintain satvik conduct.
mainpuja: Evening Gauri puja as in prior Mangala Gauri; simple Vishnu aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja with prasad and meal.
daan: Food, clothes, help to dharmic causes; gifts to women.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ कल्कि नमः” or “ॐ नमो नारायणाय;” plus “ॐ गौरी नमः” for Gauri (108 each).

significance: Birth anniversary of Tulsidas, author of Ramcharitmanas; excellent for Ram‑bhakti.
katha: His life shows transformation from worldly to intense Rama‑devotee; Ramcharitmanas brought Ram‑katha to common people.
morning: Morning snan; keep Ram‑Sita image and Tulsidas image/book.
daytime: Read small portion of Ramcharitmanas; reflect on dohas; teach children.
mainpuja: Evening bhajan of Ram bhajans and aarti.
fasting-rules: No fast required; optional light satvik diet.
daan: Books, Manas copies, food to students/temples.
notes: Mantra: “श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम” 108 times.

significance: Monthly Ashtami fast for protection, strength, and removal of inner enemies.
katha: Devi promised to protect devotees remembering her on Ashtami; many treat as mini‑Navratri.
morning: Snan; Durga image; sankalpa for fast.
daytime: Upvas on fruits/milk or one‑meal; “Ya Devi Sarvabhuteshu” japa; some read part of Durga Saptashati.
mainpuja: Evening Durga puja, kumkum, flowers, incense, kheer/fruit naivedya; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja with prasad and satvik food.
daan: Food, fruits, clothes to girls and women.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108 times.

significance: Ekadashi dedicated to couples desiring worthy progeny and family harmony.
katha: Katha: King Mahijit, childless, was advised this Ekadashi; by fasting and charity he gained a virtuous son.
morning: Morning snan; Vishnu image; Ekadashi sankalpa, especially for putra/putri sukha.
daytime: No grains; fruits/milk fast; read Putrada Ekadashi katha, Vishnu Sahasranama; avoid negativity.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja, tulsi‑archana, aarti.
fasting-rules: Parana next morning on Dwadashi with tulsi‑water and light food.
daan: Food, grains, clothes; donations to child‑care or orphanages.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108/1008 times.

english-name: Vaishnava Putrada Ekadashi; 4th Shravan Somvar; Damodara Dwadashi
hindi-name: वैष्णव पुत्रदा एकादशी; चौथा श्रावण सोमवार; दामोदर द्वादशी
significance: In Vaishnava reckoning Ekadashi may shift; Damodara Dwadashi honours Krishna as Damodara; final Shravan Somvar adds Shiva grace.
katha: Damodara lila: Yashoda tied Krishna with rope round belly; symbol of love binding Infinite.
morning: Follow Ekadashi or Dwadashi depending on sampradaya; morning snan; Vishnu + Shiva images.
daytime: Ekadashi fast as above; plus Shravan Somvar Shiva upvas/japa.
mainpuja: Dwadashi: Damodara puja with butter, rope symbol; aarti; final Shravan Somvar Shiva abhishek.
fasting-rules: Parana in Dwadashi; Shravan Somvar fast broken after evening Shiva puja.
daan: Food, butter, sweets for children/poor; water, bel leaves for Shiva.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ दामोदराय नमः;” “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108 each.

english-name: 4th Mangala Gauri Vrat; Bhauma Pradosh Vrat
hindi-name: चौथा मंगला गौरी; भौम प्रदोष व्रत
significance: Final Mangala Gauri of Shravan; Bhauma (Tuesday) Pradosh for courage, land/property issues.
katha: Bhauma Pradosh katha highlights resolution of disputes, enemies, and real‑estate troubles by Shiva’s grace.
morning: Morning snan; Gauri image for women; Shiva lingam for Pradosh.
daytime: Women keep Mangala Gauri fast; everyone may keep Pradosh fast on fruits.
mainpuja: Evening: Gauri puja with shringar and sweets; then Pradosh puja to Shiva with abhishek, bilva, aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after Pradosh puja; Mangala Gauri fast ends with prasad and dinner.
daan: Bangles, clothes to women; food, ghee, grains to poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ गौरी नमः” & “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108 each.

english-name: Rigveda Upakarma; Onam (Thiruvonam in Kerala often 26/27)
muhurat: Morning sandhya & upakarma; daytime Onam feast bhaktipulse​
significance: Upakarma is renewal of Vedic study; Onam celebrates King Mahabali’s annual visit and Vamana avatar.
katha: Mahabali, beloved king, sent to netherworld by Vamana, but allowed yearly visit when his people celebrate Onam joyfully.
morning: Morning snan; Brahmins/Yajurvedis do Upakarma: thread‑change, sankalpa for study.
daytime: For Onam: pookalam (flower rangoli), house cleaning, satvik prep.
mainpuja: Vedic sandhya, homa for Upakarma; Onam: family feast (sadya) after simple puja.
fasting-rules: No fast; rather sacred feast; those doing Upakarma may keep discipline.
daan: Food, clothes, study materials; charity meals.
notes: Mantra: Gayatri for Upakarma; “ॐ नमो भगवते वामनाय” for Vamana.

english-name: Yajurveda Upakarma; Hayagriva Jayanti; Shravana Purnima Vrat
hindi-name: यजुर्वेद उपाकर्म; हयग्रीव जयंती; श्रावण पूर्णिमा
muhurat: Snan‑daan morning; Upakarma; Vishnu puja evening bhaktipulse​
significance: Yajurveda Upakarma renews Yajur veda study; Hayagriva Jayanti for knowledge and memory; Purnima vrat for charity.
katha: Hayagriva retrieved Vedas stolen by demons, symbolising restoration of wisdom.
morning: Early snan; perform Upakarma ritual if eligible; otherwise normal Vishnu puja.
daytime: Fast partial or one‑meal; japa; study scripture.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu/Hayagriva puja; Satyanarayan katha optional; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja with prasad and meal.
daan: Books, pens, education support; food to students/Brahmins.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ हयग्रीवाय नमः” 108; Vishnu mantra as above.

english-name: Varalakshmi Vrat; Raksha Bandhan; Gayatri Jayanti; Narali Purnima; Sanskrit Diwas; Chandra Grahan (Partial)
hindi-name: वरलक्ष्मी व्रत; रक्षाबंधन; गायत्री जयंती; नारियल पूर्णिमा; संस्कृत दिवस; चन्द्र ग्रहण
muhurat: Varalakshmi morning; Rakhi mid‑day; grahan as per timings bhaktipulse+1
significance: Extremely packed day: Varalakshmi for wealth & family welfare (esp. South); Raksha Bandhan for sibling bond; Gayatri Jayanti; Narali Purnima for sea‑offering; partial lunar eclipse enhances japa‑phal.
katha: Varalakshmi katha: Lakshmi appeared in dream to poor woman Charumati; by this vrat her family prospered. Rakhi legends include Krishna–Draupadi, Yama–Yamuna; Gayatri & Narali stories as in earlier months.
morning: Morning snan; married women do Varalakshmi kalash‑sthapan with Lakshmi face; brothers & sisters prepare for Rakhi.
daytime: Varalakshmi fast (fruits/one‑meal) till puja; Gayatri japa; collect coconuts for Narali; plan japa during grahan.
mainpuja: Varalakshmi puja (South): elaborate Lakshmi worship, string tying on hand; Rakhi tying mid‑day; seaside/river coconut offering (Narali); Gayatri puja; eclipse‑time japa if visible; mantra‑upasana.
fasting-rules: Varalakshmi fast ends after puja with feast; on eclipse, avoid eating during grahan; break after snan & daan.
daan: Food, clothes, gold as per capacity; coconuts; charity to women, priests, sailors/fisherfolk.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः;” “ॐ भूः भुवः स्वः तत्सवितुर्वरेण्यं…” (Gayatri) 108+; “ॐ गायत्र्यै नमः.”

significance: Start of Bhadrapada, month of Janmashtami and Ganesh Chaturthi coming up.
katha: Considered Krishna’s special month in North; also Ganesha’s in next Shukla.
morning: Morning snan; simple puja to family deities; sankalpa for month sadhana.
daytime: Plan Janmashtami/Ganesh Chaturthi preparations; choose fasts.
mainpuja: Evening diya and short aarti.
fasting-rules: No obligatory fast; optional.
daan: Food, coins to poor as “start of month” daan.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108 at month‑start.

english-name: Kajari Teej; Bahula Chaturthi; Maha Sangada Hara Chathurti; Heramba Sankashti
hindi-name: कजरी तीज; बहुला चतुर्थी; महा संगड हर चतुर्थी; हेरम्ब संकष्टी
significance: Kajari Teej for marital happiness; Bahula Chaturthi (cow worship); Heramba Sankashti (five‑faced Ganesha) for powerful obstacle‑removal.
katha: Bahula story: a cow protected her calf with truth and devotion; Ganesha as Heramba protects in dire, “sangata” situations.
morning: Morning snan; married women for Kajari Teej; cow puja arrangements.
daytime: Women keep Teej fast; do Bahula cow puja, feeding cows; Sankashti vrat all‑day fast.
mainpuja: Evening Heramba Ganesha puja with abhishek, durva, modak; Sankashti katha; Moon darshan and arghya; Teej songs.
fasting-rules: Sankashti fast ends after Moon & Ganesha offerings; Teej fast ends after evening puja; Bahula is not strict upvas.
daan: Food, fodder for cows; sweets for children; donations to Goshala.
notes: Mantra: Ganesha – “ॐ हेरम्बाय नमः/ॐ गं गणपतये नमः;” Parvati – “ॐ गौरी नमः;” 108 each as per focus.

significance: Major Teej where women fast for good husband, marital bliss, and devotion like Parvati.
katha: Parvati’s friends abducted (“hartalika”) her to forest so she could avoid unwanted marriage and do tapas for Shiva; pleased, Shiva accepted her.
morning: Early snan; married/unmarried women wear green/auspicious clothes; install Gauri image.
daytime: Strict nirjal or phalahar fast; sing Teej songs, swings, visit maternal home.
mainpuja: Gauri–Shankar puja with mehendi, bangles, sweets; vrat katha; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast usually nirjal till night, then broken after puja with prasad and satvik food.
daan: Bangles, mehendi, clothes, food to women and girls; annadaan.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ गौरी शंकराय नमः” 108 times.

significance: Birthday of Ganesha; sthapana of murti at home/temple for 1–10 days; removes vighnas and brings auspiciousness.
katha: Shiva–Parvati’s son Ganesha created as guardian; beheaded and revived with elephant head; became first worshipped before any auspicious act.
morning: Snan; install Ganesha murti during Madhyahna; take sankalpa for vrat & puja.
daytime: Observe fast or satvik one‑meal; prepare modak, laddoo, durva; decorate pandal/altar, daily aarti schedule.
mainpuja: Madhyahna or evening main puja: abhishek, 21 durva/21 modak, Ganesha Atharvashirsha, aarti; start daily aarti till Visarjan.
fasting-rules: Many keep partial fast this day; break after puja. Ongoing daily aartis do not require fast.
daan: Modak, laddoo, food, stationery to children; donations for community pandal.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times daily during festival.

significance: Vrat especially for women to purify past mistakes in monthly cycle matters and honour Saptarishis.
katha: Story of a woman who unknowingly broke rules during rajaswala; by Rishi Panchami fast and Saptarishi puja, she gained freedom from sin.
morning: Morning snan, including scrub with herbal/earth substances; draw Saptarishi symbols.
daytime: Fast on fruits or one simple meal; remember rishis, read katha.
mainpuja: Puja of Saptarishis with flowers, incense; aarti; offering of simple naivedya.
fasting-rules: Fast typically ends after evening puja with light satvik food.
daan: Food, grains, clothes to Brahmins and poor women.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ ऋषिभ्यो नमः” 108 times.

significance: Celebrates birth of Krishna; night fasting, kirtan, and abhishek bring bhakti, protection, and joy.
katha: Krishna born in Mathura prison to Devaki‑Vasudeva, shifted to Gokul; life full of leelas; removes adharma and grants love of God.
morning: Early snan; clear altar; install Bal Gopal image; vow for fast if health allows.
daytime: Nirjal or fruit fast; read Bhagavatam, Gita; bhajan, japa “Hare Krishna/Hare Ram.”
mainpuja: At midnight, abhishek of Krishna (milk, curd, honey, ghee, sugar), new clothes, cradle (jhula) puja, aarti, kirtan, prasad.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after midnight janma‑puja with charanamrit and prasad; heavier food later/next morning.
daan: Butter, sweets to children, annadan at temples.
notes: Mantra: Maha‑mantra – “हरे कृष्ण हरे कृष्ण कृष्ण कृष्ण हरे हरे, हरे राम हरे राम राम राम हरे हरे” many rounds; or “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108+ times.

significance: Youths form human pyramids to break curd‑filled pot, celebrating Krishna’s butter‑stealing leelas and teamwork.
katha: Reflects Gopas’ games with Krishna, wealth sharing, and joy.
morning: Normal snan; simple Krishna puja.
daytime: Organise/attend Dahi Handi; encourage safety; bhajans.
mainpuja: Evening aarti at home/temple.
fasting-rules: No vrat; usually feast around event.
daan: Food, sweets to participants/poor kids.
notes: Mantra: simple “गोविन्द बोलो हरि गोपाल बोलो” kirtan.

significance: Some Gaudiya/ISKCON follow Ekadashi‑based Janmashtami one day later; Nandotsav celebrates Nanda’s joy and distribution of gifts.
katha: As above, plus emphasis on sankirtan and prasad distribution.
morning: As Janmashtami: snan, sankalpa; temple darshan.
daytime: Kirtan, reading, seva in temple.
mainpuja: Midnight abhishek and aarti; next morning Nandotsav, annakut‑style bhog.
fasting-rules: Fast till midnight, then feast as per Vaishnava guidelines.
daan: Massive prasad, food to all.
notes: Mantra: Maha‑mantra japa all day.

significance: Tuesday (Bhauma) Pradosh for courage, property/litigations, and Mars‑related issues.
katha: Devotees freed from enemies and court problems by Tuesday Pradosh vrat in many kathas.
morning: Morning snan; Shiva sthapana; vow for Pradosh fast.
daytime: Fruit/milk fast; “Om Namah Shivaya” japa; avoid anger/aggression.
mainpuja: Pradosh Kaal puja: abhishek, bilva, incense, lamp, Mahamrityunjaya; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after puja with light satvik food.
daan: Masoor dal, red cloth, food to poor/war‑affected; ghee, bel to temple.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” & “ॐ अंगारकाय नमः” (Mangala) 108 each.

significance: Monthly Shivratri in dark fortnight; good for inner purification, japa, and breaking addictions.
katha: Same jyotirlinga story; focusing on Shiva at night controls mind’s restlessness.
morning: Morning snan; decide fast type; Shivalinga set.
daytime: Upvas (fruits/water); japa, reading Shiva katha.
mainpuja: Night: 1–4 prahar puja with repeated abhishek, bilva, mantra‑japa, meditation, aarti.
fasting-rules: Parana next morning after dawn Shiva & Surya puja.
daan: Food, water, blankets to poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” many malas; Mahamrityunjaya 108.

significance: Powerful Amavasya for shraddha, tarpan, and Pitru‑related remedies, just before Pitru Paksha month.
katha: Puranas stress Amavasya tarpan as duty; Bhadrapada Amavasya near rainy season end.
morning: Early snan (river if possible); set tarpan items.
daytime: Perform shraddha/tarpan; maintain satvik speech and food.
mainpuja: Simple Narayana puja and deepa in evening.
fasting-rules: Many keep one‑meal fast or general simplicity; break after daan/puja.
daan: Sesame, food, clothes, umbrellas to poor & Brahmins.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” and “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 times.

significance: Marks Vishnu changing side in Yoga‑nidra during Chaturmas; good for turning points in life, vows, and inner transformation.
katha: Devi told Yudhishthira this Ekadashi grants same punya as Vajpeya sacrifice; Vishnu rolls to other side, altering subtle cosmic currents.
morning: Early snan; Vishnu image; Ekadashi sankalpa.
daytime: No grains; fruits/milk fast; Sahasranama, Parivartini katha; symbolically review and “turn” habits.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu/Satyanarayan puja; aarti; bhajan.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi with tulsi‑water and light food.
daan: Food, grains, charity to temples/ashrams.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108/1008 times.

significance: Shukla‑paksha Pradosh for prosperity, peace, and Shiva’s grace.
katha: Pradosh legend: Shiva’s dance relieved devas from suffering; Shukla Pradosh adds bright‑fortnight prosperity aspect.
morning: Morning snan; Pradosh fast sankalpa.
daytime: Fruit/milk fast; Shiva nama‑japa, Shiv Chalisa.
mainpuja: Pradosh abhishek, bilva, dhoop‑deep, Mahamrityunjaya; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja with satvik food.
daan: Milk, curd, rice; annadan.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108; Mahamrityunjaya 108.

muhurat: Daytime/afternoon for Anant Puja; Visarjan muhurat as per panchang panchang+1
focus: Lord Anant (Vishnu with infinite snakes); Ganesha
significance: Anant Chaturdashi vrat for unending prosperity using Anant sutra (thread); also last day of public Ganesh festival with Visarjan.
katha: Story: Brahmin Kaudinya lost wealth after discarding Anant thread; after realizing mistake, he resumed vrat and regained fortune.
morning: Morning snan; draw Anant symbol (14 knots thread); Ganesha still installed.
daytime: Vrat with light food; Anant katha reading; tie Anant sutra on arm.
mainpuja: Afternoon Vishnu Anant puja, then Ganesh Visarjan procession: final aarti, immersion in water body with prayers.
fasting-rules: Those fasting break after Anant puja and Visarjan with feast.
daan: Food, clothes, sweets, threads to poor, children.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ अनन्ताय नमः” 108 times; Ganesha mantra as Visarjan ends.

significance: Full Moon for charity, Satyanarayan vrat, and transition towards Ashwin and Navratri energies.
katha: Many Satyanarayan and community kirtans done; considered auspicious close of bhadrapada’s bright half.
morning: Early snan; sankalpa for Purnima vrat.
daytime: Partial fast or one‑meal satvik; Vishnu japa, reading.
mainpuja: Evening Satyanarayan puja and katha; aarti; prasad.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja/prasad (or moonrise if following that rule).
daan: Food, grains, clothes; annadan.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नारायणाय नमः” 108 times.

english-name: Vishwakarma Puja (industry date; some regions on 17/18/20 depending solar transit)
tithi-month: Solar transit in Virgo / industrial date panchang​
significance: Worship of divine architect, patron of artisans/engineers; tools and machines are blessed.
katha: Vishwakarma seen as craftsman of gods’ weapons and palaces; this day workers thank him and pray for safety.
morning: Morning snan; decorate workplace; set Vishwakarma image at shop/factory.
daytime: Tool/vehicle puja: incense, flowers, kumkum; no machine work during puja time.
mainpuja: Aarti and prasad distribution at workplace.
fasting-rules: No fast; focus on safety and gratitude.
daan: Food, sweets to workers; safety equipment donation.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ विश्वकर्मणे नमः” 108 times.

significance: Wednesday Pradosh especially good for intellect, business, communication.
katha: Pradosh vrat plus Budha’s influence helps with clarity and good speech.
morning: Morning snan; Shiva sthapana; sankalpa.
daytime: Light fast, japa “Om Namah Shivaya;” check/plan finances, communication.
mainpuja: Pradosh abhishek, bilva, incense; Mahamrityunjaya; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after puja.
daan: Food, books, pens to students; ghee, bel to temple.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” & “ॐ बुं बुधाय नमः” 108 each.

english-name: (Alt date) Ganesh Visarjan / Anant Chaturdashi (per DrikPanchang for some states)
significance: Some regions immerse Ganesha today; treat as alternate if you followed 16 Sep for New Delhi.
katha: Same Anant/Visarjan themes.
morning: As above.
daytime: As above.
mainpuja: As above.
fasting-rules: As above.
daan: Note in Excel which date you adopt; other as “alt date”.
notes: Mantra: same as Anant/Visarjan row.

significance: Ekadashi specially for liberation of ancestors during Pitru Paksha; grants Pitru‑moksha and removes Pitru dosha.
katha: Katha: King Indrasena rescued father from Yama‑loka by keeping this Ekadashi and donating its punya to him.
morning: Early snan; tarpan for Pitru; then Vishnu image; Ekadashi sankalpa.
daytime: No grains; fruits/milk; Vishnu Sahasranama, Indira katha; remember ancestors with gratitude.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja; aarti; mental offering of punya to Pitru.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi after tarpan/Vishnu puja; offer some food in names of ancestors.
daan: Food, grains, sesame, clothes to poor/Brahmins in name of Pitru.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” and “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” 108 each.

significance: Evening Shiva fast for cleansing, peace, and health within Pitru Paksha.
katha: Same Pradosh legends; occurring in Pitru Paksha supports karmic cleaning.
morning: Morning snan; Pradosh sankalpa.
daytime: Phalahar fast; Shiva nama‑japa.
mainpuja: Pradosh abhishek with water/milk, bilva; Mahamrityunjaya; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after puja.
daan: Milk, rice, ghee; food to poor/sadhus.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108+ times.

muhurat: Snan‑daan, Pitru tarpan in morning panchang+1
significance: Key Amavasya for ancestors; marks start of Pitru Paksha; crucial for tarpan, shraddha, and remembering lineage.
katha: Bhishma and other texts stress Pitru Paksha offerings; Mahalaya songs and stories in Bengal recall Goddess and Pitru blessings.
morning: Very early snan; preferably river or at least Ganga jal bath; prepare tarpan items.
daytime: Perform elaborate tarpan/shraddha with priest if possible; keep mind deeply respectful; maintain satvik diet and thoughts.
mainpuja: Evening deepa, Narayana/Devi puja, minimal celebration; listen to Mahalaya‑type stotras if desired.
fasting-rules: Some keep fast or one‑meal satvik food; avoid non‑veg, alcohol, loud entertainment.
daan: Sesame, food, clothes to poor; feeding cows, crows, dogs as symbolic Pitru offerings.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” repeatedly during tarpan; “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 times.

significance: Start of 9‑day Sharad Navratri for Durga’s nine forms; very important for sadhana and house/inner cleansing.
katha: Legends of Devi slaying Mahishasura and other demons; each day a different form is worshipped, culminating in Vijayadashami.
morning: Early snan; clean puja area; perform Ghatasthapana (kalash with mango leaves and coconut, Durga image); take 9‑day vrat sankalpa.
daytime: Partial fast (one meal or fruits), daily reading of Durga Saptashati/Devi Kavach, japa “Ya Devi Sarvabhuteshu…”.
mainpuja: Evening aarti and bhajans; light lamp near kalash; simple naivedya.
fasting-rules: Fast pattern continues daily till Ashtami/Navami; many avoid onion/garlic throughout.
daan: Food, fruits, clothes to Kanya girls, poor women.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108 times daily.

significance: Day 2 honors Brahmacharini, giver of tapas‑shakti and steadiness in sadhana.
katha: She performed severe austerities to obtain Shiva as husband; symbolizes perseverance and simplicity.
morning: Snan; worship Brahmacharini with white flowers; offer sugar.
daytime: Continue fast (fruits/one‑meal); chant her name and read short katha.
mainpuja: Evening aarti, bhajans.
fasting-rules: Same Navratri vrat rules.
daan: Sugar, white clothes, food to students/sadhaks.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी ब्रह्मचारिण्यै नमः” 108 times.

significance: Day 3: Chandraghanta, symbol of courage and removal of fear.
katha: She bears crescent moon on forehead; rides lion; destroys enemies of dharma.
morning: Snan; worship with fragrant flowers; ring bell gently during aarti.
daytime: Fast continues; read small katha; focus on fearlessness.
mainpuja: Evening puja and aarti.
fasting-rules: As per Navratri vrata.
daan: Food, support to women facing abuse/fear.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी चन्द्रघंटायै नमः” 108 times.

significance: Day 4: Kushmanda who creates the universe; first visible Chandra of bright fortnight.
katha: Universe created from her cosmic smile; associated with health and vitality.
morning: Snan; Kushmanda puja, offer white pumpkin or malpua if possible.
daytime: Fasting pattern continues; japa; seva.
mainpuja: After sunset, Chandra Darshan: offer arghya, short Moon mantra; then aarti.
fasting-rules: Continue Navratri fast; no separate Chandra fast.
daan: Rice, sweets, buttermilk to poor.
notes: Mantra: Kushmanda – “ॐ देवी कूष्मांडायै नमः” 108; Chandra – “ॐ चन्द्राय नमः” 11.

significance: Day 5: Skandamata, mother of Kartikeya; grants children’s welfare and bhakti.
katha: She carries child Skanda on lap; worship brings motherly protection.
morning: Snan; Skandamata puja; offer bananas.
daytime: Fast and japa as usual; focus on children’s well‑being.
mainpuja: Evening aarti and bhajans.
fasting-rules: Navratri fast as per pattern.
daan: Fruits, clothes, food to children.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी स्कन्दमातायै नमः” 108.

significance: Day 6: Katyayani, powerful for marriage, removal of delayed marriage doshas.
katha: Gopis worshipped her to obtain Krishna; known as fierce warrior form.
morning: Snan; yellow clothes; puja with turmeric, yellow flowers.
daytime: Fast; read Katyayani katha; pray for right spouse/relationship harmony.
mainpuja: Evening aarti.
fasting-rules: As per Navratri vrata.
daan: Food, haldi, bangles to girls/women.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी कात्यायन्यै नमः” 108.

significance: Day 7: Kalaratri, destroyer of intense negativity, fear, black magic.
katha: She removed demons like Shumbha–Nishumbha’s hordes; fierce yet protective.
morning: Snan; red/black flowers; simple puja with deepa.
daytime: Fast; meditate on letting go of deep fears & vices.
mainpuja: Evening aarti; more japa than decoration.
fasting-rules: Vrat pattern same.
daan: Food, lamps to poor homes/temples.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी कालरात्र्यै नमः” 108.

significance: Major day of Navratri: Mahagauri, Kanya pujan, and often havan; very powerful for shuddhi and wish‑fulfilment.
katha: Mahagauri regained pure fair form after tapas and Shiva’s grace; Kanya seen as living Devi.
morning: Snan; special Durga/ Mahagauri puja; arrange Kanya pujan (9 girls + 1 boy as Bhairav ideally).
daytime: Fast till Kanya pujan; read Durga Saptashati finale; homa if possible.
mainpuja: Kanya pujan: wash feet, tilak, feed, give gifts; aarti of Durga; bhajans.
fasting-rules: Many end Navratri fast here; break after Kanya pujan with prasad and satvik food.
daan: Food, clothes, bangles to Kanya; dakshina to priests.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी महागौर्यै नमः” 108.

significance: Final day of Navratri: Siddhidatri, granter of siddhis; also used as alternate Kanya‑pujan day.
katha: She grants eight siddhis to devas and devotees; symbol of completeness.
morning: Snan; Navami puja; optionally do Kanya pujan if not done on Ashtami.
daytime: Complete Durga Saptashati; perform small homa.
mainpuja: Final Navratri aarti; distribute prasad.
fasting-rules: For those ending fast on Navami, Parana after puja/ Kanya feeding.
daan: Food, clothes, annadan at temples.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ देवी सिद्धिदात्र्यै नमः” 108.

significance: Celebrates victory of good over evil – Rama’s victory over Ravana, Devi’s victory over Mahishasura; auspicious for new ventures, vidyarambha, shastra puja.
katha: Ramayana war ends on this day; many also burn Ravana effigies; Ayudha puja marks tools/weapons worship.
morning: Morning snan; simple home puja to Durga/Rama.
daytime: Visit temple; worship tools, vehicles (Ayudha puja); children start new books/music etc.
mainpuja: Evening Ramlila/ Dussehra witnessing; aarti at home; small Shami‑tree puja where followed.
fasting-rules: No fast; feast but keep sattvik; ideal day to start new study/work.
daan: Food, books, instruments to students; charity.
notes: Mantra: “श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम” 108; or “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः”.

significance: Ekadashi for destroying sins (paap) and getting Vaikuntha‑gati; very praised in Puranas.
katha: Katha of hunter/king freed from heavy sins by this Ekadashi and Vishnu worship; even hearing its greatness gives merit.
morning: Early snan; Vishnu image; sankalpa for vrat.
daytime: No grains; fruits/milk fast; Vishnu Sahasranama, Papankusha katha; avoid harshness, lies.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu/Satyanarayan puja; aarti, bhajans.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi with tulsi‑water and light food.
daan: Food, grains, sesame, clothes to poor/Brahmins.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108/1008 times.

significance: Pradosh fast for overall forgiveness, peace, and prosperity.
katha: Devas’ troubles were removed during Pradosh by Shiva’s Tandava; hence this twilight is sacred.
morning: Morning snan; Shiva sthapana; sankalpa.
daytime: Fruit/milk fast; “Om Namah Shivaya” japa; avoid rajasic behaviour.
mainpuja: Pradosh puja: abhishek, bilva‑archana, incense, lamp; Mahamrityunjaya japa; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after puja with satvik meal.
daan: Milk, rice, sweets; bel leaves and ghee to temple.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” and “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108 each.

significance: Night of brightest full moon, believed that Lakshmi roams asking “Ko‑jaagarti?” (who is awake); special kheer exposed to moonlight is taken as medicine‑like prasad.
katha: Legends link it to Lakshmi’s blessing of wakeful devotees, and Krishna’s Rasa‑lila with Gopis under Sharad moon.
morning: Early snan; brief Lakshmi puja; arrange for night vigil.
daytime: Light daytime food or partial fast; prepare thick kheer in evening.
mainpuja: After moonrise, Lakshmi puja, aarti; keep kheer in moonlight; consume later night/next morning as prasad.
fasting-rules: Some do night‑long jagran; fast may be fruits/one‑meal; break after night puja or next morning.
daan: Food, sweets, clothes to poor, especially women.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” 108 times; also do some “श्री सूक्त” recitation.

significance: North Indian married women’s fast for husband’s long life, marital harmony.
katha: Legend of Veeravati and other queens who regained husbands by steadfast Karwa fast.
morning: Before sunrise (sargi), eat from mother‑in‑law; then snan; adorn in bridal‑like clothes; vow nirjal fast.
daytime: Vrat katha reading in afternoon; mehendi, songs; maintain nirjal upvas.
mainpuja: Evening Gauri/Chauth Mata puja; after Moonrise, view Moon through sieve, then husband’s face; water offered; fast broken.
fasting-rules: Strict nirjal from pre‑dawn till post‑Moonrise; then full meal.
daan: Food, clothes, cosmetics to married women and poor girls.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ गौरी नमः” 108; simple “सातों जन्म तुम्हारा सुहाग रहे” sankalpically.

significance: Mothers fast for well‑being and long life of children.
katha: Ahoi Mata once accidentally harmed baby animal; by vrat she atoned and her children prospered.
morning: Morning snan; mothers draw/keep Ahoi image; sankalpa for fast.
daytime: Nirjal or fruits‑only; day spent in sewa and katha listening.
mainpuja: At starsight, offer water & prasad to Ahoi Mata; aarti; then see stars with thread‑count; break fast.
fasting-rules: Fast from sunrise till starsight; then satvik meal.
daan: Food, clothes to children; charity in name of kids.
notes: Mantra: simple “अहोई माता” prayer; “ॐ अहोई मातायै नमः” 108.

significance: Ekadashi for peace, prosperity, and gradual liberation; named for Rama.
katha: Katha of once‑sinful persons redeemed by this fast and Rama‑nama; emphasises truth, non‑violence along with fast.
morning: Morning snan; Vishnu/Rama image; Ekadashi sankalpa.
daytime: No grains; fruits/milk; Ramayana reading and Rama‑nama japa.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu–Rama puja; aarti; bhajans.
fasting-rules: Dwadashi Parana with tulsi‑water and light food.
daan: Food, blankets, grains; donations for Ramayana pravachan.
notes: Mantra: “श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम” 108/1008 times.

english-name: Dhanteras / Dhantrayodashi (per some lists, alt: 26 Oct)
significance: First day of Diwali cluster; buying utensils/gold; also Dhanvantari Jayanti for health.
katha: Dhanvantari emerged with Amrita from Samudra‑manthan; house lit to invite Lakshmi.
morning: Morning snan; home/business cleaning.
daytime: Auspicious buying of metal, gold, utensils (within reason); prep for puja.
mainpuja: Evening Lakshmi‑Kuber–Dhanvantari puja; rows of diyas at door/windows.
fasting-rules: No fast; focus on satvik feast and puja.
daan: Food, medicines, money to sick/hospitals; grains to poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” and “ॐ श्रीं क्लीं महामायै नमः” 108; for health “ॐ नमो धन्वन्तरये नमः”.

english-name: Labh Panchami (regional; last Diwali business day)
significance: In Gujarat and business communities, marks final Diwali day; auspicious to start books/ledgers and business ventures.
katha: Traders reopen account books after Diwali, invoking Ganesha–Lakshmi for profit (labh) and good customers.
morning: Snan; small puja at home or shop.
daytime: Clean shop/office; decorate with rangoli and flowers; write “Shubh Labh” on ledgers.
mainpuja: Short Lakshmi–Ganesha puja at workplace; aarti; prasad.
fasting-rules: No vrat; only auspicious business start.
daan: Sweets, food to staff; charity as per ability.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” 108 times.

significance: Marks waking of Vishnu after 4‑month Chaturmas; marriages and big functions restart.
katha: Lakshmi asked Vishnu to rest; from Devshayani to this day he sleeps; waking symbolises fresh auspicious period.
morning: Early snan; Vishnu image; Ekadashi sankalpa.
daytime: No grains; fruits/milk fast; chanting Vishnu Sahasranama, Dev Uthani katha; many do tulsi‑parikrama.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu/Hari‑Lakshmi puja; aarti; pushpanjali; some perform symbolic Tulsi–Shaligram marriage.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi with tulsi‑water and satvik food.
daan: Food, grains, clothes; donations to temples/ashrams.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108/1008 times.

significance: Ceremonial marriage of Tulsi with Vishnu/Shaligram, symbolising end of Chaturmas and start of wedding season.
katha: Tulsi once Vrinda, wife of Jalandhar; after events, became sacred plant; Vishnu promised to wed her.
morning: Morning snan; decorate Tulsi pot as bride; arrange small Shaligram/ Vishnu as groom.
