daytime: Prepare mandap, light decorations, sweets; invite family.
mainpuja: Evening Tulsi Vivah: kanyadaan, mangalsutra/cloth tying between Tulsi & Shaligram, mantra, aarti, kirtan.
fasting-rules: No strict fast; some maintain light satvik food till evening puja.
daan: Food, clothes, sweets to Brahmins and poor couples.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ तुलस्यै नमः” and “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 each.

significance: First Diwali day: buying utensils/gold, lighting lamps; also Dhanvantari Jayanti for health.
katha: Dhanvantari emerged with Amrita pot at Samudra‑manthan; families light lamps to invite wealth and good health.
morning: Morning snan; clean and decorate home/shop.
daytime: Purchase metal/utensils/gold within capacity; prepare for evening diya‑lighting.
mainpuja: Evening Lakshmi‑Kuber–Dhanvantari puja; light rows of diyas at doors and windows; aarti.
fasting-rules: No vrat; feast with satvik items.
daan: Food, medicines, money to hospitals/poor; oil, lamps for temples.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” and “ॐ नमो धन्वन्तरये नमः” 108 each.

english-name: Naraka Chaturdashi (Choti Diwali) & Lakshmi Puja / Diwali; Narak Nivaran Chaturdashi; Kedar Gauri Vrat
muhurat: Abhyang snan at Brahma‑muhurta; Lakshmi Puja in Pradosh Kaal bookmypoojaonline+1
focus: Lakshmi, Ganesha, Naraka‑asur story, Kedar Gauri
significance: Main Diwali night: Lakshmi–Ganesh puja for wealth and auspiciousness; Naraka Chaturdashi bath for sin‑removal.
katha: Krishna killed Narakasura this tithi and freed 16,000 women; Lakshmi roams to bless clean, lit houses.
morning: Pre‑dawn oil/ubtan bath (Abhyang snan); wear new/clean clothes.
daytime: Clean house; decorate with rangoli, lamps; prepare sweets & savouries; avoid anger/quarrels.
mainpuja: In Pradosh (after sunset, before ~9 PM), main Lakshmi–Ganesh puja: kalash, coins, sweets, Lakshmi aarti, Ganesha Atharvashirsha; then diyas, crackers (moderate).
fasting-rules: No fast; day of feasting; some keep light until Lakshmi puja done.
daan: Food, clothes, sweets to poor; donations to workers/house‑helps.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ श्रीं महालक्ष्म्यै नमः” 108; “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108.

significance: Celebrates Krishna lifting Govardhan hill to protect Vrindavan; also Bali Pratipada–honouring King Bali.
katha: Krishna urged villagers to worship Govardhan instead of Indra; he then lifted hill for 7 days.
morning: Morning snan; draw/ mound Govardhan (cow‑dung hill or rangoli).
daytime: Prepare many bhog items (Annakut); decorate cows if possible.
mainpuja: Govardhan puja: circumambulate mound, offer food, kirtan “Govardhan Giridhari”; feast with family.
fasting-rules: No vrat; festival feast day.
daan: Food, fodder for cows; annadan at temples.
notes: Mantra: “गोवर्धनधारी गोपाल कृष्ण की जय” or “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108 times.

significance: Sisters pray for brothers’ long life and well‑being, similar to Raksha Bandhan but post‑Diwali.
katha: Yamuna welcomed brother Yama, applied tilak and fed him; he granted boon that sisters doing similar will bless brothers.
morning: Morning snan; sisters prepare thali.
daytime: Brothers visit sisters’ homes.
mainpuja: Tilak, aarti of brother, sweet feeding; brother gives gifts; simple family meal.
fasting-rules: No fast; only simple auspicious conduct.
daan: Gifts, food, clothes to sisters; charity in siblings’ names.
notes: Mantra: simple sankalp‑prayer; “ॐ यमाय नमः” (for protection) few times.

muhurat: Snan‑daan at sunrise; deepdaan at night panchang+1
significance: Dev Diwali: devas celebrate Diwali on Kartik Purnima; extremely sacred for Ganga snan, charity, lamps on ghats.
katha: Legends: Tripurasura slain by Shiva on this day (Tripurari Purnima); Vishnu took Matsya avatar; many tirthas considered especially powerful.
morning: Early snan (river or Ganga jal); take vow for charity and lamps.
daytime: Maintain satvik food; visit temple/tirtha; annadan.
mainpuja: Night: light rows of lamps at home/riverbank; Vishnu–Shiva–Ganga puja; Satyanarayan katha optional.
fasting-rules: Some keep partial fast; break after night puja or next morning.
daan: Food, clothes, lamps, grains to poor and at ghats.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” and “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108 each.

significance: Start of very sacred month, good for Krishna and Lakshmi worship, especially on Thursdays.
katha: Krishna in Gita calls Margashirsha his own month; associated with devotion and prosperity.
morning: Snan; simple puja to Krishna/Lakshmi.
daytime: Decide extra sadhana: e.g. Margashirsha Thursdays puja, japa.
mainpuja: Evening diya and aarti.
fasting-rules: No special fast; monthly discipline focus.
daan: Food/coins to poor as month‑start daan.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108 at month start.

significance: Monthly Sankashti fast for removal of obstacles, illness, financial issues.
katha: Typical katha: a family/king saved from disaster by this vrat and hearing the story; Ganesha promises to remove “sankat”.
morning: Pre‑dawn snan; establish Ganesha; fast sankalpa.
daytime: Nirjal/fruit fast; Ganesh japa; read or hear Sankashti katha.
mainpuja: Evening puja, abhishek, durva, modak; katha; aarti; Moon darshan and arghya.
fasting-rules: Fast ends only after Moon sight and offering to Moon & Ganesha; then prasad and light meal.
daan: Modak, laddoo, books for children.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times.

significance: Ekadashi commemorating birth of Ekadashi Devi; best for conquering negative energies and tamasic tendencies.
katha: Vishnu created Ekadashi Devi from his energy to defeat demon Murasura; those who fast gain protection.
morning: Morning snan; Vishnu image; Ekadashi sankalpa.
daytime: No grains; fruits/milk; read Utpanna Ekadashi katha and Sahasranama; avoid lethargy.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu puja, aarti, bhajans.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi after sunrise with tulsi‑water then light food.
daan: Food, grains, blankets to poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108/1008.

significance: Evening fast for forgiveness, inner peace, health.
katha: Pradosh legends: Shiva’s dance at this time freed devas from suffering.
morning: Morning snan; vow for Pradosh fast; Shivalinga set.
daytime: Fruit/milk fast; “Om Namah Shivaya” japa; read Shiva katha.
mainpuja: Pradosh Kaal abhishek, bilva‑archana, incense, deep; Mahamrityunjaya japa; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after puja with satvik meal.
daan: Milk, rice, white sweets; bel leaves to temple.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” & “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108 each.

significance: Monthly Shivratri, very strong with cool season starting; good for deep japa and meditation.
katha: Same jyotirlinga pillar‑of‑light story; emphasises transcending mind.
morning: Snan; fast decision; Shivalinga.
daytime: Upvas; japa, parayan of Shiva stotra.
mainpuja: Four‑prahar night‑puja if possible, with repeated abhishek, bilva, aarti.
fasting-rules: Parana next morning after dawn Shiva & Surya puja.
daan: Food, water, woollens to poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” many malas; Mahamrityunjaya 108.

muhurat: Snan‑daan; Pitru tarpan in morning panchang​
significance: New moon for ancestor offerings and charity before new lunar month.
katha: Standard Amavasya shraddha texts emphasise peace for Pitru and removal of doshas.
morning: Early snan; set tarpan materials (water, sesame).
daytime: Perform tarpan/shraddha (with priest or simple mantras); keep sattvik.
mainpuja: Evening diya, Narayana aarti.
fasting-rules: Some keep one‑meal or fruit fast; break after daan.
daan: Food, sesame, clothes to poor/Brahmins in ancestor names.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” 108; “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108.

muhurat: Just after sunset, first moon sight panchang​
significance: First waxing Moon brings mental peace and emotional balance.
katha: Story of Chandra’s curse and refuge with Shiva; honouring Moon calms mind.
morning: Normal snan; prepare plate with rice, sweets, water.
daytime: Maintain gentle, sattvik mood.
mainpuja: At first sight of Moon, offer arghya with water/rice; chant Chandra mantra; aarti.
fasting-rules: No fast; some break voluntary upvas after Chandra Darshan.
daan: Rice, milk sweets to children/poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ चन्द्राय नमः” 11–27 times.

significance: Monthly Vinayaka Chaturthi for success, wisdom, and removal of obstacles in new bright fortnight.
katha: Similar to other Chaturthis; many do day‑fast and evening Ganesha puja.
morning: Morning snan; Ganesha sthapana; sankalpa.
daytime: Fruit fast; japa of “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah”; read Ganesha katha.
mainpuja: Evening abhishek, durva, sweets; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after evening puja.
daan: Modak, laddoo, books to students.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008.

significance: Very important in South (especially Tamil Nadu) for victory, protection, overcoming enemies.
katha: Remembers Skanda’s victory over Surapadma; devotees do fast, kavacham recitation, visit Murugan temples.
morning: Morning snan; Murugan image/Vel.
daytime: Upvas on fruits/milk; recite Skanda Shashti Kavacham; visit temple if possible.
mainpuja: Evening aarti, coconut/banana offerings.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja with satvik food.
daan: Food, sweets, gifts to boys/students.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ सरवनभवाय नमः” 108.

significance: Monthly Ashtami fast for protection and shakti.
katha: Devi promises to destroy inner and outer enemies of devotees remembering her on Ashtami.
morning: Snan; Durga image; sankalpa.
daytime: Fruit/one‑meal fast; “Ya Devi Sarvabhuteshu” recitation; small Saptashati path if possible.
mainpuja: Evening puja, kumkum, flowers, kheer/fruit naivedya; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after evening puja with prasad and food.
daan: Food, fruits, clothes to women/girls.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108.

significance: Akshay Navami believed to grant inexhaustible punya and prosperity; Jagaddhatri Puja (esp. Bengal) celebrates Devi as supporter of universe.
katha: Legends link day to the start of Satya Yuga farming and also to Krishnavatar’s pastimes; Jagaddhatri icon shows Devi subduing egoic lion.
morning: Morning snan; simple Vishnu or Devi puja.
daytime: Optional fast or simple satvik one‑meal; japa; charity.
mainpuja: Evening Jagaddhatri puja where celebrated: elaborate aarti, lamps, bhajans.
fasting-rules: No strict rules; vrat can be moderate as per strength.
daan: Food, grains, clothes; lamps.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” or “ॐ जगद्धात्र्यै नमः” 108.

english-name: (Regional) Jagaddhatri Puja Continues / Margashirsha Somvar Begins
significance: In some places Jagaddhatri continues; Margashirsha Mondays are good for Shiva/ Krishna upasana.
katha: Gita verse “māsānām mārgaśīrṣo ’ham” encourages enhanced sadhana in this month; Monday fasts popular.
morning: Snan; Shiva and/or Krishna puja.
daytime: Optional Somvar fast; japa; study of Gita.
mainpuja: Evening aarti; personal sankalpa for all Margashirsha Mondays.
fasting-rules: If fasting, break after evening puja.
daan: Food, books, clothes to poor/students.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” 108; “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108.

significance: Ekadashi when Ekadashi Devi was “born” from Vishnu’s shakti; powerful to conquer tamas and strong negative impulses.
katha: Vishnu manifested Ekadashi Devi to slay demon Mura; observing this fast is said to destroy heavy sins and grant protection.
morning: Early snan; Vishnu murti; Ekadashi sankalpa.
daytime: No grains; fruits/milk; read Utpanna Ekadashi katha and Sahasranama; maintain sattva.
mainpuja: Evening Vishnu/Satyanarayan puja; aarti; bhajans.
fasting-rules: Parana on Dwadashi with tulsi‑water first, then light satvik food.
daan: Food, grains, blankets to poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108/1008 times.

muhurat: Pradosh Kaal (~5:45–8:10 PM); night Nishita drikpanchang​
significance: Combination of Saturday Pradosh (Shani Pradosh) and monthly Shivaratri; good for Shani dosha, karmic cleansing, and deep Shiva bhakti.
katha: Stories tell of prisoners and debtors freed after Shani Pradosh vrat; Shivaratri recalls Shiva’s jyotirlinga form beyond time.
morning: Morning snan; Shivalinga sthapana; sankalpa for fast.
daytime: Upvas on fruits/milk; “Om Namah Shivaya” japa; Shani stotra (if needed).
mainpuja: Pradosh: abhishek, bilva, Mahamrityunjaya; later night: 2–4 pra­har Shivaratri puja, more abhishek and japa.
fasting-rules: Fast typically from sunrise till next morning after dawn Shiva puja and Surya arghya.
daan: Food, black sesame, blankets, shoes to poor; oil & lamps to Shani/ Shiva temples.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” many malas; “ॐ शं शनैश्चराय नमः” 108.

significance: In some Shakta traditions, celebrates Devi in child form, symbolising innocence and pure shakti.
katha: Bala Tripurasundari appears as young girl who is nevertheless supreme Shakti, granting siddhi and protection.
morning: Snan; set small Devi‑as‑balika image; simple puja.
daytime: Gentle japa, reading Devi stotras; keep sattvik mood.
mainpuja: Aarti, offering of sweets, fruits.
fasting-rules: No strict fast; optional light diet.
daan: Sweets, clothes to girl children.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ ऐं बालिकायै नमः” or “ॐ श्रीं ह्रीं क्लीं त्रिपुर sundaryai नमः” 108.

significance: New moon for shraddha/tarpan and charity, with cool season aiding seva.
katha: As with other Amavasyas, Pitru are believed to receive offerings and bless descendants.
morning: Early snan (river or with Ganga jal); prepare tarpan plate.
daytime: Perform tarpan/shraddha; maintain sattvik diet, calm speech.
mainpuja: Evening diya, Narayana/Kul‑devata aarti.
fasting-rules: Many keep one‑meal satvik or fruit fast; break after daan/puja.
daan: Food, sesame, clothes, blankets to poor & Brahmins.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ पितृभ्यः स्वधा नमः” and “ॐ नमो नारायणाय” 108 each.

muhurat: Just after sunset, first moon sight drikpanchang​
significance: First waxing Moon after Amavasya; promotes mental peace and emotional balance.
katha: Chandra, once cursed, found refuge with Shiva; honouring him balances mind.
morning: Normal snan; ready plate with rice, sweets, water.
daytime: Maintain peaceful, sattvik thoughts.
mainpuja: At first sight of Moon, offer arghya with water/rice; chant Chandra mantra; aarti.
fasting-rules: No fast; some break optional upvas after Moon sight.
daan: Rice and milk sweets to children/poor.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ चन्द्राय नमः” 11–27 times.

significance: Celebrates divine marriage of Rama–Sita; auspicious for marriages and grihastha dharma.
katha: Ramayana describes Janakpur wedding on this tithi; devotees recall ideal couple virtues.
morning: Snan; place Ram–Sita images; decorate as wedding scene.
daytime: Simple fast or satvik one‑meal; read Ramayana wedding chapter; teach children.
mainpuja: In temple/home, enact symbolic kalyanam; aarti; distribute prasad.
fasting-rules: No strict fast; optional upvas ends after puja.
daan: Food, clothes to couples, assistance for poor weddings.
notes: Mantra: “श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम” 108; “सीताराम” japa.

significance: Observed especially in South/West as victory and protection vrat, and regional Champa Shashti for Shiva/Devi.
katha: Skanda’s battles and victory over Surapadma are remembered; Champa Shashti has local myths of demons slain.
morning: Morning snan; Murugan image/Vel, or regional deity.
daytime: Upvas on fruits/milk; recite Skanda Shashti Kavacham or local stotras.
mainpuja: Evening aarti, coconut, banana offerings.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after puja with satvik meal.
daan: Food, sweets, gifts to boys and students.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ सरवनभवाय नमः” 108 times.

significance: Sun’s transit into Dhanu rashi; good for charity, pilgrimage planning, spiritual focus.
katha: Dhanu is linked to dharma, higher learning, pilgrimage; Surya’s entry supports such pursuits.
morning: Snan; offer arghya to Sun with Surya mantra.
daytime: Reflect on dharmic goals; plan tirtha/snana, donations.
mainpuja: Evening diya; brief Surya aarti.
fasting-rules: No fast required; optional light satvik diet.
daan: Food, ghee, grains; support to students/spiritual centres.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ घृणि सू्र्याय नमः” 108.

significance: Monthly Ashtami fast for protection, shakti, and success.
katha: Devi promised to protect those remembering her regularly on Ashtami.
morning: Snan; Durga image; sankalpa.
daytime: Fruit or one‑meal fast; recite “Ya Devi Sarvabhuteshu” and short Saptashati portion.
mainpuja: Evening Durga puja with kumkum, flowers, kheer/fruit; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after puja with prasad and food.
daan: Food, fruits, clothes to girls/women.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ दुं दुर्गायै नमः” 108.

hindi-name: वैकुण्ठ एकादशी / मोक्षदा एकादशी / गीता जयंती
muhurat: Sunrise–next sunrise; Gita path during day drikpanchang+2
significance: Most important Ekadashi in many Vaishnava temples; gates of Vaikuntha symbolically open; also Mokshada Ekadashi and Gita Jayanti (Kurukshetra day).
katha: Story of a king whose father suffered in hell; by observing Mokshada Ekadashi and donating its punya, he saved him; Gita spoken on this day.
morning: Early snan; Vishnu image; Ekadashi sankalpa; place Gita near altar.
daytime: No grains; fruits/milk; read at least one chapter or selected verses of Gita; Mokshada katha.
mainpuja: Evening Vaikuntha Narayana puja; aarti; in temples, special Vaikuntha Dwara darshan.
fasting-rules: Dwadashi Parana with tulsi‑water and light food; keep mind on moksha‑sankalpa.
daan: Food, books (Gita), clothes; support to Gita teaching projects.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय” 108/1008; plus reading Gita verses.

significance: Evening fast for forgiveness, health, prosperity in bright fortnight.
katha: Pradosh legends: Shiva’s Tandava at this time removes devotees’ sins and sorrows.
morning: Morning snan; Shiva sthapana; sankalpa.
daytime: Fruits/milk fast; “Om Namah Shivaya” japa.
mainpuja: Pradosh abhishek, bilva‑puja, incense, lamp; Mahamrityunjaya japa; aarti.
fasting-rules: Fast ends after puja with satvik meal.
daan: Milk, rice, sweets; bel leaves, oil lamps to temple.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ नमः शिवाय” & “ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे…” 108 each.

muhurat: Snan‑daan morning; Dattatreya puja any time; night satsang drikpanchang+1
significance: Full Moon considered climax of Margashirsha month; Dattatreya Jayanti for seekers of wisdom, avadhuta‑marg, and guru‑kripa.
katha: Dattatreya, son of Atri–Anasuya, is guru of gurus, embodiment of Trinity; his life teaches learning from all of nature.
morning: Early snan (river if possible); set Dattatreya or simple trinity symbol; Purnima vrat sankalpa.
daytime: Partial fast or one‑meal; read Dattatreya Upanishad stories or Avadhuta Gita excerpts; japa.
mainpuja: Evening satsang or bhajan; Dattatreya puja with incense, flowers; aarti; moon‑darshan.
fasting-rules: Fast broken after night puja or next morning with satvik food.
daan: Food, clothes, blankets; support to sadhus, gurukuls.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ द्रां दत्तात्रेयाय नमः” 108/1008 times.

tithi-month: Pausha Krishna Chaturthi (North) / Margashirsha Shukla Chaturthi (alt)
significance: Monthly Ganesha fast for removing obstacles and giving success near year‑end.
katha: Generic Sankashti katha: struggling devotees rescued from misfortune by this vrat and Ganesha’s grace.
morning: Pre‑dawn snan; Ganesha sthapana; fast sankalpa.
daytime: Nirjal/fruit fast; “Om Gam Ganapataye Namah” japa; Atharvashirsha recitation.
mainpuja: Evening puja, abhishek, durva, modak; katha; aarti; Moon darshan and arghya.
fasting-rules: Fast ends only after Moon sight and offering; then prasad and light meal.
daan: Modak, laddoo, stationery for children, donations for students.
notes: Mantra: “ॐ गं गणपतये नमः” 108/1008 times.

english-name: (No major national festival; year‑end sadhana focus)
significance: Good day to review year’s sadhana, renew sankalpa for next year, and do gratitude japa.
katha: Not scripturally fixed, but widely used for introspection and planning with dharmic focus.
morning: Morning snan; short puja to Ishta Devata.
daytime: List key learnings, vrats done, plans for coming year’s festivals and seva.
mainpuja: Evening deepa, japa, and sankalpa writing.
fasting-rules: No fast required; keep food satvik and modest.
daan: Food, coins to poor; resolve for planned, systematic daan next year.
notes: Mantra: choose your ishta‑mantra (e.g. “ॐ नमः शिवाय” / “ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय”) 108+ with gratitude bhava.
